verses.textEn: And Simon went into Galilee, and he engaged in many battles with the Gentiles, and the Gentiles were crushed before his face, and he pursued them even to the gates of Ptolemais.
verses.textLa: Et abiit Simon in Galilæam, et commisit prælia multa cum gentibus: et contritæ sunt gentes a facie eius, et persecutus est eos usque ad portam

verses.textEn: And there fell of the Gentiles nearly three thousand men, and he took their spoils.
verses.textLa: Ptolemaidis: et ceciderunt de gentibus fere tria millia virorum, et accepit spolia eorum,

verses.textEn: And he took with him those who were in Galilee and in Arbatta, with their wives and children, and all that was theirs, and he led them into Judea with great rejoicing.
verses.textLa: et assumpsit eos, qui erant in Galilæa, et in Arbatis cum uxoribus, et natis, et omnibus quæ erant illis, et adduxit in Iudæam cum lætitia magna.

verses.textEn: And Judas Maccabeus, and Jonathan his brother, crossed over the Jordan, and they traveled three days’ journey through the desert.
verses.textLa: Et Iudas Machabæus, et Ionathas frater eius transierunt Iordanem, et abierunt viam trium dierum per desertum.

verses.textEn: And the Nabateans met them, and they accepted them peacefully, and they described to them all that had happened to their brothers in the land of Gilead,
verses.textLa: Et occurrerunt eis Nabuthæi, et susceperunt eos pacifice, et narraverunt eis omnia, quæ acciderant fratribus eorum in Galaaditide,

verses.textEn: and that many of them were trapped in Bozrah, and Bosor, and Alema, and in Chaspho, and Maked, and Carnaim. All these are large and fortified cities.
verses.textLa: et quia multi ex eis comprehensi sunt in Barasa, et Bosor, et in Alimis, et in Casphor, et Mageth, et Carnaim: hæ omnes civitates munitæ, et magnæ.

verses.textEn: Moreover, they were held in their grasp in the other cities of Gilead, and they had arranged to move their army, on the next day, to these cities, and to seize them, and to destroy them all in one day.
verses.textLa: Sed et in ceteris civitatibus Galaaditidis tenentur comprehensi, et in crastinum constituerunt admovere exercitum civitatibus his, et comprehendere, et tollere eos in una die.

verses.textEn: Then Judas and his army unexpectedly turned their path into the desert, to Bosor, and they occupied the city. And he killed every male by the edge of the sword, and took all their spoils, and burned it with fire.
verses.textLa: Et convertit Iudas, et exercitus eius, viam in desertum Bosor repente, et occupavit civitatem: et occidit omnem masculum in ore gladii, et accepit omnia spolia eorum, et succendit eam igni.

verses.textEn: And they arose from there by night, and they went forth all the way to the fortress.
verses.textLa: Et surrexerunt inde nocte, et ibant usque ad munitionem.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, at first light, when they lifted up their eyes, behold, there was a multitude of people, which could not be numbered, bringing ladders and machines, in order to seize the fortress, and to assault them.
verses.textLa: Et factum est diluculo, cum elevassent oculos suos, ecce populus multus, cuius non erat numerus, portantes scalas, et machinas ut comprehenderent munitionem, et expugnarent eos.

verses.textEn: And Judas saw that the fight had begun, and the cry of the battle went up to heaven like a trumpet, and a great cry went out of the city.
verses.textLa: Et vidit Iudas, quia cœpit bellum, et clamor belli ascendit ad cælum sicut tuba, et clamor magnus de civitate:

verses.textEn: And he said to his army, “Fight today on behalf of your brothers.”
verses.textLa: et dixit exercitui suo: Pugnate hodie pro fratribus vestris.

verses.textEn: And he came, with three companies behind them, and they sounded the trumpets, and they cried out in prayer.
verses.textLa: Et venit tribus ordinibus post eos, et exclamaverunt tubis, et clamaverunt in oratione.

verses.textEn: And the camp of Timothy knew that it was Maccabeus, and they took flight before his face. And they struck them with a great scourging. And there fell from them in that day nearly eight thousand men.
verses.textLa: Et cognoverunt castra Timothei quia Machabæus est, et refugerunt a facie eius: et percusserunt eos plaga magna. Et ceciderunt ex eis in die illa fere octo millia virorum.

verses.textEn: And Judas diverted to Mizpah, and he fought and seized it. And he killed all of its males, and he took its spoils, and he burned it with fire.
verses.textLa: Et divertit Iudas in Maspha, et expugnavit, et cepit eam: et occidit omnem masculum eius, et sumpsit spolia eius, et succendit eam igni.

verses.textEn: From there, he continued on, and he seized Chaspho, and Maked, and Bosor, and the rest of the cities of Gilead.
verses.textLa: Inde perrexit, et cepit Casbon, et Mageth, et Bosor, et reliquas civitates Galaaditidis.

verses.textEn: But after these events, Timothy gathered together another army, and he positioned his camp opposite Raphon, across the torrent.
verses.textLa: Post hæc autem verba congregavit Timotheus exercitum alium, et castra posuit contra Raphon trans torrentem.

verses.textEn: And Judas sent men to catch sight of the army. And they reported back to him, saying: “All the nations that surround us have assembled before him, with an exceedingly great army.
verses.textLa: Et misit Iudas speculari exercitum: et renunciaverunt ei, dicentes: Quia convenerunt ad eum omnes gentes, quæ in circuitu nostro sunt, exercitus multus nimis:

verses.textEn: And they have brought the Arabians as auxiliaries to them, and they have set up camp across the torrent, in preparation to come against you in battle.” And Judas went to meet them.
verses.textLa: et Arabas conduxerunt in auxilium sibi, et castra posuerunt trans torrentem, parati ad te venire in prælium. Et abiit Iudas obviam illis.

verses.textEn: And Timothy said to the leaders of his army: “When Judas and his army approach, close to the torrent of water, if he crosses over to us first, we will not be able to withstand him. For he will be able to prevail against us.
verses.textLa: Et ait Timotheus principibus exercitus sui: Cum appropinquaverit Iudas, et exercitus eius ad torrentem aquæ: si transierit ad nos prior, non poterimus sustinere eum: quia potens poterit adversum nos.

verses.textEn: If, truly, he is afraid to cross over, and so he sets up camp across the river, we will cross over to them, and we will prevail against him.”
verses.textLa: Si vero timuerit transire, et posuerit castra extra flumen, transfretamus ad eos, et poterimus adversus illum.

verses.textEn: But when Judas approached, close to the torrent of water, he stationed the scribes of the people near the torrent, and he commanded them, saying, “Permit no man to stay behind, but let all come into the battle.”
verses.textLa: Ut autem appropinquavit Iudas ad torrentem aquæ, statuit scribas populi secus torrentem, et mandavit eis, dicens: Neminem hominem reliqueritis: sed veniant omnes in prælium.

verses.textEn: And he crossed over to them first, and all the people after him. And all the Gentiles were crushed before their face, and they threw away their weapons, and they fled to the temple that was in Carnaim.
verses.textLa: Et transfretavit ad illos prior, et omnis populus post eum, et contritæ sunt omnes gentes a facie eorum, et proiecerunt arma sua, et fugerunt ad fanum, quod erat in Carnaim.

verses.textEn: And he occupied that city, and he burned the temple with fire, along with all the things that were in it. And Carnaim was subdued, and it could not stand against the face of Judas.
verses.textLa: Et occupavit ipsam civitatem, et fanum succendit igni cum omnibus, qui erant in ipso: et oppressa est Carnaim, et non potuit sustinere contra faciem Iudæ.

verses.textEn: And Judas gathered together all the Israelites who were in the land of Gilead, from the least even to the greatest, with their wives and children, and a very great army, to come into the land of Judah.
verses.textLa: Et congregavit Iudas universos Israelitas, qui erant in Galaaditide, a minimo usque ad maximum, et uxores eorum, et natos, et exercitum magnum valde ut venirent in terram Iuda.

verses.textEn: And they came as far as Ephron. And this was a great city, positioned at the entrance, strongly fortified, and there was no way to go around it on the right or on the left, but the path was through the midst of it.
verses.textLa: Et venerunt usque Ephron: et hæc civitas magna in ingressu posita, munita valde, et non erat declinare ab ea dextera vel sinistra, sed per mediam iter erat.

verses.textEn: And those who were in the city shut themselves in and barricaded the gates with stones. And so Judas sent to them with words of peace,
verses.textLa: Et incluserunt se qui erant in civitate, et obstruxerunt portas lapidibus: et misit ad eos Iudas verbis pacificis,

verses.textEn: saying, “Let us cross through your land, to go into our own land, and no one will harm you; we will only cross through on foot.” But they were not willing to open to them.
verses.textLa: dicens: Transeamus per terram vestram, ut eamus in terram nostram: et nemo vobis nocebit: tantum pedibus transibimus. Et nolebant eis aperire.

verses.textEn: Then Judas instructed a proclamation to be made in the camp, that they would engage them, each one from the place where he was.
verses.textLa: Et præcepit Iudas prædicare in castris, ut applicarent unusquisque in quo erat loco.

verses.textEn: And the men of the army drew close. And he assaulted that city all day and all night. And the city was delivered into his hand.
verses.textLa: Et applicuerunt se viri virtutis: et oppugnavit civitatem illam tota die, et tota nocte, et tradita est civitas in manu eius:

verses.textEn: And they destroyed every male with the edge of the sword, and he eradicated the city, and he took its spoils, and he crossed through the entire city, over those who had been slain.
verses.textLa: et peremerunt omnem masculum in ore gladii, et eradicavit eam, et accepit spolia eius, et transivit per totam civitatem super interfectos.
verses.notes: Or, ‘over their dead bodies.’

verses.textEn: Then they crossed over the Jordan to the great plain that is opposite the face of Bethshan.
verses.textLa: Et transgressi sunt Iordanem in campo magno, contra faciem Bethsan.

verses.textEn: And Judas was gathering the stragglers and exhorting the people, throughout the entire way, until they came into the land of Judah.
verses.textLa: Et erat Iudas congregans extremos, et exhortabatur populum per totam viam, donec venirent in terram Iuda:

verses.textEn: And they ascended to mount Zion with joy and gladness, and they offered holocausts, because not one of them had fallen, until they had returned in peace.
verses.textLa: et ascenderunt in montem Sion cum lætitia, et gaudio, et obtulerunt holocausta, quod nemo ex eis cecidisset donec reverterentur in pace.

verses.textEn: Now in the days that Judas and Jonathan were in the land of Gilead, and Simon his brother was in Galilee against the face of Ptolemais:
verses.textLa: Et in diebus, quibus erat Iudas, et Ionathas in terra Galaad, et Simon frater eius in Galilæa contra faciem Ptolemaidis,

verses.textEn: Joseph, the son of Zachariah, and Azariah, the leader of the army, heard good things about the battles that were fought.
verses.textLa: audivit Iosephus Zachariæ filius, et Azarias princeps virtutis, res bene gestas, et prælia quæ facta sunt,

verses.textEn: And he said, “Let us also make a name for ourselves, and let us go to fight against the Gentiles that are all around us.”
verses.textLa: et dixit: Faciamus et ipsi nobis nomen, et eamus pugnare adversus gentes quæ in circuitu nostro sunt.

verses.textEn: And he gave orders to those who were in his army, and they went out towards Jamnia.
verses.textLa: Et præcepit his, qui erant in exercitu suo, et abierunt Iamniam.

verses.textEn: And Gorgias and his men exited the city, to meet them in the fight.
verses.textLa: Et exivit Gorgias de civitate, et viri eius obviam illis in pugnam.

verses.textEn: And Joseph and Azariah were forced to flee, even to the borders of Judea. And there fell on that day, from the people of Israel, up to two thousand men, and it was a great defeat for the people.
verses.textLa: Et fugati sunt Iosephus, et Azarias usque in fines Iudææ: et ceciderunt illo die de populo Israel ad duo millia viri, et facta est fuga magna in populo:

verses.textEn: For they did not listen to Judas and his brothers, supposing that they should act boldly.
verses.textLa: quia non audierunt Iudam, et fratres eius, existimantes fortiter se facturos.

verses.textEn: But these were not of the offspring of those men by whom salvation was brought to Israel.
verses.textLa: Ipsi autem non erant de semine virorum illorum, per quos salus facta est in Israel.

verses.textEn: And the men of Judah were magnified greatly in the sight of all Israel and of all the nations where their name was heard.
verses.textLa: Et viri Iuda magnificati sunt valde in conspectu omnis Israel, et gentium omnium ubi audiebatur nomen eorum.

verses.textEn: And the people gathered to them with favorable acclamations.
verses.textLa: Et convenerunt ad eos fausta acclamantes.

verses.textEn: And so Judas and his brothers went out and assailed the sons of Esau, in the land that is toward the south, and he struck Hebron and her sister cities, and he burned its walls and the towers all around it with fire.
verses.textLa: Et exivit Iudas, et fratres eius, et expugnabant filios Esau in terra, quæ ad Austrum est, et percussit Chebron et filias eius: et muros eius, et turres succendit igni in circuitu.

verses.textEn: And he moved his camp to go into the land of the foreigners, and he traveled through Samaria.
verses.textLa: Et movit castra ut iret in terram alienigenarum, et perambulabat Samariam.

verses.textEn: In that day, some priests fell in battle. Since they desired to act boldly, they went out, without counsel, into the battle.
verses.textLa: In die illa ceciderunt sacerdotes in bello, dum volunt fortiter facere, dum sine consilio exeunt in prælium.

verses.textEn: And Judas turned aside to Azotus, into the land of the foreigners, and he destroyed their altars, and he burned the statues of their gods with fire. And he seized the spoils of the cities, and he returned to the land of Judah.
verses.textLa: Et declinavit Iudas in Azotum in terram alienigenarum, et diruit aras eorum, et sculptilia deorum ipsorum succendit igni: et cepit spolia civitatum, et reversus est in terram Iuda.

verses.textEn: And king Antiochus was traveling through the upper regions, and he heard that the city of Elymais in Persia was very noble and abundant in silver and gold,
verses.textLa: Et rex Antiochus perambulabat superiores regiones, et audivit esse civitatem Elymaidem in Perside nobilissimam, et copiosam in argento, et auro,

verses.textEn: and that the temple in it was very opulent, and that there were, in that place, coverings of gold, and breastplates and shields, which Alexander, the son of Philip, king of Macedonia, who reigned first in Greece, had left behind.
verses.textLa: templumque in ea locuples valde: et illic velamina aurea, et loricæ, et scuta, quæ reliquit Alexander Philippi rex Macedo, qui regnavit primus in Græcia.
verses.notes: In this context and eschatologically, Alexander represents the great Catholic monarch, who will rule even over the Arab, Persian, and Muslim nations of the Middle East. He will leave behind great wealth and an opulent basilica in Persia (Iran).

verses.textEn: So he came and sought to seize the city and to pillage it. And he was not able, because this plan became known to those who were in the city.
verses.textLa: Et venit, et quærebat capere civitatem, et deprædari eam: et non potuit, quoniam innotuit sermo his, qui erant in civitate:

verses.textEn: And they rose up in battle, and he fled away from there, and he departed with great sadness, and he returned into Babylon.
verses.textLa: et insurrexerunt in prælium, et fugit inde, et abiit cum tristitia magna, et reversus est in Babyloniam.

verses.textEn: And someone arrived to report to him in Persia, that those who were in the land of Judah were forced to flee the camp,
verses.textLa: Et venit qui nunciaret ei in Perside, quia fugata sunt castra, quæ erant in terra Iuda:

verses.textEn: and that Lysias went forth with a particularly strong army, and he was forced to flee before the face of the Jews, and that they were strengthened by the weapons, and resources, and many spoils which they seized from the camps they demolished,
verses.textLa: et quia abiit Lysias cum virtute forti in primis, et fugatus est a facie Iudæorum, et invaluerunt armis, et viribus, et spoliis multis, quæ ceperunt de castris, quæ exciderunt:

verses.textEn: and that they had destroyed the abomination, which he had established on the altar that was in Jerusalem, and that the sanctuary, just as before, had been encircled with high walls, along with Bethzur, his city.
verses.textLa: et quia diruerunt abominationem, quam ædificaverat super altare, quod erat in Ierusalem, et sanctificationem, sicut prius, circumdederunt muris excelsis, sed et Bethsuram civitatem suam.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when the king heard these words, he was terrified and very moved. And he fell down on his bed, and he fell into feebleness out of grief. For it had not happened to him as he had intended.
verses.textLa: Et factum est ut audivit rex sermones istos, expavit, et commotus est valde: et decidit in lectum, et incidit in languorem præ tristitia, quia non factum est ei sicut cogitabat.

verses.textEn: And he was in that place through many days. For a great grief was renewed in him, and he concluded that he would die.
verses.textLa: Et erat illic per dies multos: quia renovata est in eo tristitia magna, et arbitratus est se mori.

verses.textEn: And he called all his friends, and he said to them: “Sleep has withdrawn from my eyes, and I am declining, and my heart has collapsed out of anxiety.
verses.textLa: Et vocavit omnes amicos suos, et dixit illis: Recessit somnus ab oculis meis, et concidi, et corrui corde præ solicitudine:

verses.textEn: And I said in my heart: How much trouble has come to me, and what floods of sorrow there are, where I am now! I used to be cheerful and beloved in my power!
verses.textLa: et dixi in corde meo: In quantam tribulationem deveni, et in quos fluctus tristitiæ, in qua nunc sum: qui iucundus eram, et dilectus in potestate mea!

verses.textEn: Truly, now, I remember the evils that I did in Jerusalem, from which place I also took away all the spoils of gold and silver that were in it, and I sent to carry away the inhabitants of Judah without cause.
verses.textLa: Nunc vero reminiscor malorum, quæ feci in Ierusalem, unde et abstuli omnia spolia aurea, et argentea, quæ erant in ea, et misi auferre habitantes Iudæam sine causa.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I know that it is because of this that these evils have found me. And behold, I perish with great sorrow in a foreign land.”
verses.textLa: Cognovi ergo quia propterea invenerunt me mala ista: et ecce pereo tristitia magna in terra aliena.

verses.textEn: Then he called Philip, one of his friends, and he placed him first over all his kingdom.
verses.textLa: Et vocavit Philippum, unum de amicis suis, et præposuit eum super universum regnum suum:

verses.textEn: And he gave him the diadem, and his robe, and his ring, so that he would guide Antiochus, his son, and raise him, and so that he would reign.
verses.textLa: et dedit ei diadema, et stolam suam, et annulum, ut adduceret Antiochum filium suum, et nutriret eum, et regnaret.

verses.textEn: And king Antiochus died there, in the one hundred and forty-ninth year.
verses.textLa: Et mortuus est illic Antiochus rex anno centesimo quadragesimo nono.

verses.textEn: And Lysias knew that the king was dead, and he appointed Antiochus, his son, to reign, whom he had raised from adolescence. And he called his name Eupator.
verses.textLa: Et cognovit Lysias, quoniam mortuus est rex, et constituit regnare Antiochum filium eius, quem nutrivit adolescentem: et vocavit nomen eius Eupator.

verses.textEn: And those who were in the stronghold had enclosed the Israelites by surrounding the holy places. And they continually sought to do evil to them and to support the Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Et hi, qui erant in arce, concluserant Israel in circuitu sanctorum: et quærebant eis mala semper, et firmamentum Gentium.

verses.textEn: And Judas intended to disperse them. And he called together all the people, in order to besiege them.
verses.textLa: Et cogitavit Iudas disperdere eos: et convocavit universum populum, ut obsiderent eos.

verses.textEn: And they came together and besieged them in the one hundred and fiftieth year, and they made catapults and other machines.
verses.textLa: Et convenerunt simul, et obsederunt eos anno centesimo quinquagesimo, et fecerunt balistas, et machinas.

verses.textEn: And certain ones of these, who were besieged, escaped. And some of the impious out of Israel joined themselves to them.
verses.textLa: Et exierunt quidam ex eis, qui obsidebantur: et adiunxerunt se illis aliqui impii ex Israel,

verses.textEn: And they went to the king, and they said: “How long will you not act with judgment and vindicate our brothers?
verses.textLa: et abierunt ad regem, et dixerunt: Quousque non facis iudicium, et vindicas fratres nostros?

verses.textEn: We resolved to serve your father, and to walk according to his precepts, and to obey his edicts.
verses.textLa: Nos decrevimus servire patri tuo, et ambulare in præceptis eius, et obsequi edictis eius:

verses.textEn: And because of this, the sons of our people have alienated themselves from us, and they have put to death as many of us as they could find, and they have torn apart our inheritances.
verses.textLa: et filii populi nostri propter hoc alienabant se a nobis, et quicumque inveniebantur ex nobis, interficiebantur, et hereditates nostræ diripiebantur.

verses.textEn: And they have not extended their hand against us only, but also against all within our borders.
verses.textLa: Et non ad nos tantum extenderunt manum, sed et in omnes fines nostros.

verses.textEn: And behold, this day they have taken a position near the stronghold of Jerusalem to occupy it, and they have fortified the stronghold of Bethzur.
verses.textLa: Et ecce applicuerunt hodie ad arcem Ierusalem occupare eam, et munitionem Bethsuram munierunt:

verses.textEn: And, unless you quickly act to prevent them, they will do greater things than these, and you will not be able to subdue them.”
verses.textLa: et nisi præveneris eos velocius, maiora, quam hæc, facient, et non poteris obtinere eos.

verses.textEn: And the king was angry when he heard this. And he called together all his friends, and the leaders of his army, and those who were over the horsemen.
verses.textLa: Et iratus est rex, ut hæc audivit: et convocavit omnes amicos suos, et principes exercitus sui, et eos, qui super equites erant.

verses.textEn: But there even came to him mercenary armies from other kingdoms and from the islands of the sea.
verses.textLa: Sed et de regnis aliis, et de insulis maritimis venerunt ad eum exercitus conductitii.

verses.textEn: And the number of his army was one hundred thousand footmen, and twenty thousand horsemen, and thirty-two elephants trained for battle.
verses.textLa: Et erat numerus exercitus eius, centum millia peditum, et viginti millia equitum, et elephanti trigintaduo, docti ad prælium.

verses.textEn: And they traveled through Idumea, and they took a position near Bethzur. And they fought for many days, and they made machines of war. But they came out and burnt them with fire, and they fought manfully.
verses.textLa: Et venerunt per Idumæam, et applicuerunt ad Bethsuram, et pugnaverunt dies multos, et fecerunt machinas et exierunt, et succenderunt eas igni, et pugnaverunt viriliter.

verses.textEn: And Judas departed from the stronghold, and he moved the camp to Bethzechariah, opposite the camp of the king.
verses.textLa: Et recessit Iudas ab arce, et movit castra ad Bethzacharam contra castra regis.

verses.textEn: And the king rose up, before it was light, and he forced his troops to march toward the way of Bethzechariah. And the armies prepared themselves for battle, and they sounded the trumpets.
verses.textLa: Et surrexit rex ante lucem, et concitavit exercitus in impetum contra viam Bethzacharam: et comparaverunt se exercitus in prælium, et tubis cecinerunt:

verses.textEn: And they showed the elephants the blood of grapes and mulberries, to provoke them to fight.
verses.textLa: et elephantis ostenderunt sanguinem uvæ et mori, ad acuendos eos in prælium:

verses.textEn: And they divided the beasts by the legions, and there stood by every elephant a thousand men, with shields joined together and with brass helmets on their heads. And five hundred well-ordered horsemen were chosen for every beast.
verses.textLa: et diviserunt bestias per legiones: et astiterunt singulis elephantis mille viri in loricis concatenatis, et galeæ æreæ in capitibus eorum: et quingenti equites ordinati unicuique bestiæ electi erant.

verses.textEn: These were ready beforehand, and wherever the beast was, they were there; and whenever it moved, they moved, and they did not depart from it.
verses.textLa: Hi ante tempus ubicumque erat bestia, ibi erant: et quocumque ibat, ibant, et non discedebant ab ea.

verses.textEn: Moreover, upon them there were strong wooden turrets, watching over every beast, with machines upon them, and on them were thirty-two valiant men, who fought from above, and an Indian to rule each beast.
verses.textLa: Sed et turres ligneæ super eos firmæ protegentes super singulas bestias: et super eas machinæ: et super singulas viri virtutis triginta duo, qui pugnabant desuper: et Indus magister bestiæ.
verses.notes: Obviously, there were not 32 men on each of the 32 elephants. There was one man fighting on each of the 32 elephants, with an Indian on each to govern the beast.

verses.textEn: And the rest of the horsemen, he stationed here and there, in two parts, with trumpets to stir up the army and to urge on those who were slow to move within its legions.
verses.textLa: Et residuum equitatum hinc et inde statuit in duas partes, tubis exercitum commovere, et perurgere constipatos in legionibus eius.

verses.textEn: And so, when the sun reflected off the shields of gold and of brass, the mountains were resplendent from them, and they glowed like lamps of fire.
verses.textLa: Et ut refulsit sol in clypeos aureos, et æreos, resplenduerunt montes ab eis, et resplenduerunt sicut lampades ignis.

verses.textEn: And part of the king’s army was divided to the high mountains, and the other part to the low places. And they went forth with order and caution.
verses.textLa: Et distincta est pars exercitus regis per montes excelsos, et alia per loca humilia: et ibant caute et ordinate.

verses.textEn: And all the inhabitants of the land were shaken at the voice of their multitude, and at the advance of the company, and at the clash of the armor. For the army was very great and strong.
verses.textLa: Et commovebantur omnes inhabitantes terram a voce multitudinis, et incessu turbæ, et collisione armorum: erat enim exercitus magnus valde, et fortis.

verses.textEn: And Judas and his army drew near for battle. And there fell of the king’s army six hundred men.
verses.textLa: Et appropiavit Iudas, et exercitus eius in prælium: et ceciderunt de exercitu regis sexcenti viri.

verses.textEn: And Eleazar, the son of Saura, saw one of the beasts shielded with the king’s shield, and it was higher than the other beasts. So it seemed to him that the king must be on it.
verses.textLa: Et vidit Eleazar filius Saura unam de bestiis loricatam loricis regis: et erat eminens super ceteras bestias. Et visum est ei quod in ea esset rex:

verses.textEn: And he gave himself for the freedom of his people, and to obtain for himself a name in eternity.
verses.textLa: et dedit se ut liberaret populum suum, et acquireret sibi nomen æternum.

verses.textEn: And he ran up to it boldly in the midst of the legion, killing on the right and on the left, and they fell down before him on this side and that.
verses.textLa: Et cucurrit ad eam audacter in medio legionis interficiens a dextris, et a sinistris, et cadebant ab eo huc atque illuc.

verses.textEn: And he went between the feet of the elephant, and put himself under it, and he killed it. And it fell to the ground upon him, and he died there.
verses.textLa: Et ivit sub pedes elephantis, et supposuit se ei, et occidit eum: et cecidit in terram super ipsum, et mortuus est illic.

verses.textEn: And, seeing the strength of the king and the forcefulness of his army, they turned themselves away from them.
verses.textLa: Et videntes virtutem regis, et impetum exercitus eius, diverterunt se ab eis.

verses.textEn: But the king’s camp went up against them in Jerusalem. And the king’s camp took up a position near Judea and Mount Zion.
verses.textLa: Castra autem regis ascenderunt contra eos in Ierusalem, et applicuerunt castra regis ad Iudæam, et montem Sion.

verses.textEn: And he made peace with those who were in Bethzur. And they went out of the city, because they had no provisions in their confinement, for it was the Sabbath of the land.
verses.textLa: Et fecit pacem cum his, qui erant in Bethsura: et exierunt de civitate, quia non erant eis ibi alimenta conclusis, quia Sabbata erant terræ.

verses.textEn: And the king captured Bethzur, and he stationed a garrison there to keep it.
verses.textLa: Et comprehendit rex Bethsuram: et constituit illic custodiam servare eam.

verses.textEn: And he turned his camp against the place of sanctification for many days. And he stationed there catapults and other machines: machines to cast fire, and windlasses to cast stones and darts, and small catapults to cast arrows and metal.
verses.textLa: Et convertit castra ad locum sanctificationis dies multos: et statuit illic balistas, et machinas, et ignis iacula, et tormenta ad lapides iactandos, et spicula, et scorpios ad mittendas sagittas, et fundibula.
verses.notes: The word ‘iacula’ indicates a machine for casting something; in this context it does not refer to javelins. The first two items in the list are general, ‘balistas, et machinas,’ whereas the next set of items is the specific list. In other words, they had catapults and other machines, including... and then the items are listed. The word ‘fundibula’ is derived from the word referring to pouring or casting metals, so in this context it refers to metal that was used in small catapults, not to stone slings.

verses.textEn: But they also made machines against their machines, and they fought for many days.
verses.textLa: Fecerunt autem et ipsi machinas adversus machinas eorum, et pugnaverunt dies multos.

verses.textEn: But there were no foods in the city, because it was the seventh year. And those who had remained in Judea were from the Gentiles, so they consumed all that they had left from what had been stored up.
verses.textLa: Escæ autem non erant in civitate, eo quod septimus annus esset: et qui remanserant in Iudæa de Gentibus, consumpserant reliquias eorum, quæ repositæ fuerant.
verses.notes: It was the seventh year, that is, the Sabbatical year, and apparently the 150th year of the kingdom of the Greeks. The footnotes to the RSV gives the year as 162 B.C. This agrees with my dates for the Sabbatical years, given in my book, Important Dates in the Lives of Jesus and Mary, Appendix I, Chart 7 (though you have to count backwards from the earliest date in that chart). The year 162 B.C. was a Sabbatical year, beginning in Nissan and continuing through early 163 B.C.

verses.textEn: And there remained in the holy places a few men, for the famine had prevailed over them. And they were scattered, each one to his own place.
verses.textLa: Et remanserunt in sanctis viri pauci, quoniam obtinuerat eos fames: et dispersi sunt unusquisque in locum suum.

verses.textEn: Then Lysias heard that Philip, whom king Antiochus had appointed, when he was still alive, to raise his son, Antiochus, and to reign,
verses.textLa: Et audivit Lysias quod Philippus, quem constituerat rex Antiochus, cum adhuc viveret, ut nutriret Antiochum filium suum, et regnaret,

verses.textEn: had returned from Persia and Media, with the army that went with him, and that he sought to take upon himself the affairs of the kingdom.
verses.textLa: reversus esset a Perside, et Media, et exercitus qui abierat cum ipso, et quia quærebat suscipere regni negotia:

verses.textEn: He hurried to go and to say to the king and the commanders of the army: “We are weakened every day, and our food is limited, and the place that we besiege is strong, and it is incumbent upon us to put the kingdom in order.
verses.textLa: festinavit ire, et dicere ad regem, et duces exercitus: Deficimus quotidie, et esca nobis modica est, et locus, quem obsidemus, est munitus, et incumbit nobis ordinare de regno.

verses.textEn: And so now, let us bestow a pledge to these men, and make peace with them and with all their nation.
verses.textLa: Nunc itaque demus dextras hominibus istis, et faciamus cum illis pacem, et cum omni gente eorum:

verses.textEn: And let us establish for them that they may walk according to their own laws, just as before. For, because of their laws, which we despised, they have become angry and have done all these things.”
verses.textLa: et constituamus illis ut ambulent in legitimis suis sicut prius. Propter legitima enim ipsorum, quæ despeximus, irati sunt, et fecerunt omnia hæc.

verses.textEn: And the idea was pleasing in the sight of the king and the leaders. And he sent to them to make peace. And they accepted it.
verses.textLa: Et placuit sermo in conspectu regis, et principum: et misit ad eos pacem facere: et receperunt illam.

verses.textEn: And the king and the leaders swore to them. And they went out of the stronghold.
verses.textLa: Et iuravit illis rex, et principes: et exierunt de munitione.

verses.textEn: Then the king entered into Mount Zion, and saw the fortifications of the place, and so he abruptly broke the oath that he had sworn, and he commanded the surrounding wall to be destroyed.
verses.textLa: Et intravit rex montem Sion, et vidit munitionem loci: et rupit citius iuramentum, quod iuravit: et mandavit destruere murum in gyro.

verses.textEn: And he departed in haste and returned to Antioch, where he found Philip ruling the city. And he fought against him and occupied the city.
verses.textLa: Et discessit festinanter, et reversus est Antiochiam, et invenit Philippum dominantem civitati: et pugnavit adversus eum, et occupavit civitatem.

verses.textEn: In the one hundred and fifty-first year, Demetrius, the son of Seleucus, departed from the city of Rome, and he went up with a few men to a maritime city, and he reigned there.
verses.textLa: Anno centesimo quinquagesimo primo exiit Demetrius Seleuci filius ab urbe Roma, et ascendit cum paucis viris in civitatem maritimam, et regnavit illic.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, as he entered into the house of the kingdom of his fathers, the army captured Antiochus and Lysias, to bring them to him.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, ut ingressus est domum regni patrum suorum, comprehendit exercitus Antiochum, et Lysiam, ut adducerent eos ad eum.

verses.textEn: And the matter became known to him, and he said, “Do not show me their face.”
verses.textLa: Et res ei innotuit: et ait: Nolite mihi ostendere faciem eorum.

verses.textEn: And so the army killed them. And Demetrius sat upon the throne of his kingdom.
verses.textLa: Et occidit eos exercitus. Et sedit Demetrius super sedem regni sui:

verses.textEn: And there came to him iniquitous and impious men from Israel. And Alcimus was their leader, who wanted to be made a priest.
verses.textLa: et venerunt ad eum viri iniqui et impii ex Israel: et Alcimus dux eorum, qui volebat fieri sacerdos.
verses.notes: Alcimus wanted to be made a priest, i.e. he was not even a priest at any level, yet he not only wanted to be priest, but, as subsequent verses indicate, he wanted to be high priest.

verses.textEn: And they accused the people to the king, saying: “Judas and his brothers have destroyed all your friends, and he has scattered us from our land.
verses.textLa: Et accusaverunt populum apud regem, dicentes: Perdidit Iudas, et fratres eius omnes amicos tuos, et nos dispersit de terra nostra.

verses.textEn: Now, therefore, send a man, whom you trust, and let him go and see all the destruction he has done to us and to the regions of the king. And let him punish all his friends and their helpers.”
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo mitte virum, cui credis, ut eat, et videat exterminium omne, quod fecit nobis, et regionibus regis: et puniat omnes amicos eius, et adiutores eorum.

verses.textEn: And so the king chose, from among his friends, Bacchides, who ruled across the great river in the kingdom, and who was faithful to the king. And he sent him
verses.textLa: Et elegit rex ex amicis suis Bacchidem, qui dominabatur trans flumen magnum in regno, et fidelem regi: et misit eum,

verses.textEn: to see the destruction that Judas had done. Moreover, he appointed the wicked Alcimus to the priesthood, and he commanded him to take revenge on the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: ut videret exterminium, quod fecit Iudas: sed et Alcimum impium constituit in sacerdotium, et mandavit ei facere ultionem in filios Israel.
verses.notes: This event is a foreshadowing of the time, about halfway through the Antichrist’s reign (in the mid 2430’s), when the Antichrist will try to destroy the Church from within by supporting apostates and heretics, and by appointing a wicked person as high priest over them (an antipope). Alcimus foreshadows that antipope, who is not even validly ordained, being appointed, not by the Bishops, but by an evil ruler.

verses.textEn: And they rose up and came forth with a great army into the land of Judah. And they sent messengers, who spoke to Judas and his brothers with words of peace, in deceitfulness.
verses.textLa: Et surrexerunt, et venerunt cum exercitu magno in terram Iuda: et miserunt nuncios, et locuti sunt ad Iudam, et ad fratres eius verbis pacificis in dolo.

verses.textEn: But they did not heed their words, for they saw that they arrived with a great army.
verses.textLa: Et non intenderunt sermonibus eorum: viderunt enim quia venerunt cum exercitu magno.

verses.textEn: Then there assembled to Alcimus and Bacchides, a congregation of scribes, to seek just terms.
verses.textLa: Et convenerunt ad Alcimum, et Bacchidem congregatio scribarum requirere quæ iusta sunt:

verses.textEn: And first, the Hasideans, who were among the sons of Israel, also sought peace from them.
verses.textLa: et primi, Assidæi qui erant in filiis Israel, et exquirebant ab eis pacem.

verses.textEn: For they said, “A man who is a priest from the offspring of Aaron has arrived; he will not deceive us.”
verses.textLa: Dixerunt enim: Homo sacerdos de semine Aaron venit, non decipiet nos:

verses.textEn: And he spoke to them peaceful words, and he swore to them, saying, “We will not carry out any evil against you or your friends.”
verses.textLa: et locutus est cum eis verba pacifica: et iuravit illis, dicens: Non inferemus vobis malum, neque amicis vestris.

verses.textEn: And they believed him. And he captured sixty of their men and killed them in one day, according to the word that is written:
verses.textLa: Et crediderunt ei: Et comprehendit ex eis sexaginta viros, et occidit eos in una die secundum verbum, quod scriptum est:

verses.textEn: The flesh of your saints, and their blood, they have poured out all around Jerusalem, and there was no one who would bury them.
verses.textLa: Carnes sanctorum tuorum, et sanguinem ipsorum effuderunt in circuitu Ierusalem, et non erat qui sepeliret.

verses.textEn: Then fear and trembling hovered over all the people. For they said: “There is no truth or judgment among them. For they have transgressed the agreement and the oath that they swore.”
verses.textLa: Et incubuit timor, et tremor in omnem populum: quia dixerunt: Non est veritas, et iudicium in eis: transgressi sunt enim constitutum, et iusiurandum quod iuraverunt.

verses.textEn: And Bacchides moved the camp from Jerusalem, and he took up a position at Bethzaith. And he sent and captured many of those who had fled from him, and some of the people he killed in sacrifice, and he threw them into a great pit.
verses.textLa: Et movit Bacchides castra ab Ierusalem, et applicuit in Bethzecha: et misit, et comprehendit multos ex eis, qui a se effugerant, et quosdam de populo mactavit, et in puteum magnum proiecit.
verses.notes: The word ‘mactavit’ is an unusual word used to refer to killing in the context of a pagan sacrifice, i.e. a human sacrifice.

verses.textEn: Then he committed the country to Alcimus, and he left behind troops with him to assist him. And so Bacchides went away to the king.
verses.textLa: Et commisit regionem Alcimo, et reliquit cum eo auxilium in adiutorium ipsi. Et abiit Bacchides ad regem:

verses.textEn: And Alcimus did what he pleased by means of his leadership of the priesthood.
verses.textLa: et satis agebat Alcimus pro principatu sacerdotii sui.

verses.textEn: And all those who disturbed the people assembled before him, and they obtained the land of Judah, and they caused a great scourging in Israel.
verses.textLa: Et convenerunt ad eum omnes, qui perturbabant populum suum, et obtinuerunt terram Iuda, et fecerunt plagam magnam in Israel.

verses.textEn: And Judas saw all the evils that Alcimus, and those who were with him, did to the sons of Israel, even more than the Gentiles did.
verses.textLa: Et vidit Iudas omnia mala quæ fecit Alcimus, et qui cum eo erant, filiis Israel, multo plus quam Gentes.
verses.notes: Those apostate and heretical Christians (who are not truly Christians at all) who are given power by the Antichrist, will do much more to harm the faithful than soldiers ever could.

verses.textEn: And he went out into all the parts surrounding Judea, and he took vengeance on the men who had rebelled, and they ceased to go forth into the region any longer.
verses.textLa: Et exiit in omnes fines Iudææ in circuitu, et fecit vindictam in viros desertores, et cessaverunt ultra exire in regionem.

verses.textEn: But Alcimus saw that Judas, and those who were with him, prevailed. And he knew that he was not able to withstand them. And so he returned to the king, and he accused them of many crimes.
verses.textLa: Vidit autem Alcimus quod prævaluit Iudas, et qui cum eo erant: et cognovit quia non potest sustinere eos, et regressus est ad regem, et accusavit eos multis criminibus.

verses.textEn: And the king sent Nicanor, one of his principal noblemen, who was a cultivator of hostility against Israel. And he commanded him to overthrow the people.
verses.textLa: Et misit rex Nicanorem, unum ex principibus suis nobilioribus: qui erat inimicitias exercens contra Israel: et mandavit ei evertere populum.

verses.textEn: And Nicanor came to Jerusalem with a great army, and he sent to Judas and his brothers words of peace, with deceitfulness,
verses.textLa: Et venit Nicanor in Ierusalem cum exercitu magno, et misit ad Iudam et ad fratres eius verbis pacificis cum dolo,

verses.textEn: saying: “Let there be no fighting between me and you. I will come with a few men, to see your faces with peace.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Non sit pugna inter me et vos: veniam cum viris paucis, ut videam facies vestras cum pace.

verses.textEn: And he came to Judas, and they greeted one another in turns, peaceably. And the enemies were prepared to abduct Judas.
verses.textLa: Et venit ad Iudam, et salutaverunt se invicem pacifice: et hostes parati erant rapere Iudam.

verses.textEn: And the plan became known to Judas, that he came to him with deceit. And so he became very afraid of him, and he was no longer willing to see his face.
verses.textLa: Et innotuit sermo Iudæ quoniam cum dolo venerat ad eum: et conterritus est ab eo, et amplius noluit videre faciem eius.

verses.textEn: And Nicanor knew that his plan had been exposed, and he went out to meet Judas in battle near Capharsalama.
verses.textLa: Et cognovit Nicanor quoniam denudatum est consilium eius: et exivit obviam Iudæ in pugnam iuxta Capharsalama.

verses.textEn: And there fell of the army of Nicanor nearly five thousand men, and they fled into the city of David.
verses.textLa: Et ceciderunt de Nicanoris exercitu fere quinque millia viri, et fugerunt in civitatem David.

verses.textEn: And after these events, Nicanor ascended to mount Zion. And some of the priests of the people went out to greet him in peace, and to show him the holocausts that were offered for the king.
verses.textLa: Et post hæc verba ascendit Nicanor in montem Sion: et exierunt de sacerdotibus populi salutare eum in pace, et demonstrare ei holocautomata, quæ offerebantur pro rege.

verses.textEn: But he mocked and despised them, and he defiled them. And he spoke arrogantly,
verses.textLa: Et irridens sprevit eos, et polluit: et locutus est superbe,

verses.textEn: and he swore with anger, saying, “Unless Judas and his army have been delivered into my hands, when I return in peace, I will burn this house.” And he went out with great anger.
verses.textLa: et iuravit cum ira, dicens: Nisi traditus fuerit Iudas, et exercitus eius in manus meas, continuo cum regressus fuero in pace, succendam domum istam. Et exiit cum ira magna.

verses.textEn: And the priests went in and stood before the face of the altar and the temple. And weeping, they said:
verses.textLa: Et intraverunt sacerdotes, et steterunt ante faciem altaris et templi: et flentes dixerunt:

verses.textEn: “You, O Lord, have chosen this house so that your name may be invoked in it, so that it may be a house of prayer and supplication for your people.
verses.textLa: Tu Domine elegisti domum istam ad invocandum nomen tuum in ea, ut esset domus orationis et obsecrationis populo tuo.

verses.textEn: Accomplish vindication with this man and his army, and let them fall by the sword. Remember their blasphemies, and do not allow them to continue.”
verses.textLa: Fac vindictam in homine isto, et exercitu eius, et cadant in gladio: memento blasphemias eorum, et ne dederis eis ut permaneant.

verses.textEn: Then Nicanor departed from Jerusalem, and he positioned his camp near Bethhoron, and an army of Syria met him there.
verses.textLa: Et exiit Nicanor ab Ierusalem, et castra applicuit ad Bethoron: et occurrit illi exercitus Syriæ.

verses.textEn: And Judas took a position in Adasa with three thousand men. And Judas prayed, and he said:
verses.textLa: Et Iudas applicuit in Adarsa cum tribus millibus viris: et oravit Iudas, et dixit:

verses.textEn: “O Lord, when those who were sent by king Sennacherib blasphemed against you, an angel went out and struck one hundred and eighty-five thousand of them.
verses.textLa: Qui missi erant a rege Sennacherib, Domine, quia blasphemaverunt te, exiit angelus, et percussit ex eis centum octogintaquinque millia:

verses.textEn: Just so, crush this army in our sight today, and so let the others know that he has spoken evil against your sanctuary. And judge him according to his wickedness.”
verses.textLa: sic contere exercitum istum in conspectu nostro hodie: et sciant ceteri quia male locutus est super sancta tua: et iudica illum secundum malitiam illius.

verses.textEn: And the armies were sent into battle together on the thirteenth day of the month of Adar. And the camp of Nicanor was crushed, and he himself was among the first slain in the battle.
verses.textLa: Et commiserunt exercitus prælium tertiadecima die mensis Adar: et contrita sunt castra Nicanoris, et cecidit ipse primus in prælio.

verses.textEn: So then, when his army saw that Nicanor had fallen, they threw away their weapons and fled.
verses.textLa: Ut autem vidit exercitus eius quia cecidisset Nicanor, proiecerunt arma sua, et fugerunt:

verses.textEn: And they pursued them for one day’s journey from Adasa, even until one comes into Gazara, and they sounded the trumpets after them with signals.
verses.textLa: et persecuti sunt eos viam unius diei ab Adazer usquequo veniatur in Gazara, et tubis cecinerunt post eos cum significationibus:

verses.textEn: And they went forth from all of the towns all around Judea. And they herded them with the horns, and they turned back again to them, and they were all felled with the sword, and there was not so much as one of them left behind.
verses.textLa: et exierunt de omnibus castellis Iudææ in circuitu, et ventilabant eos cornibus, et convertebantur iterum ad eos, et ceciderunt omnes gladio, et non est relictus ex eis nec unus.
verses.notes: Take no prisoners.

verses.textEn: And they took their spoils like a prey, and they cut off the head of Nicanor, and his right hand, which he had extended arrogantly, and they brought it, and hung it up opposite Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et acceperunt spolia eorum in prædam: et caput Nicanoris amputaverunt, et dexteram eius, quam extenderat superbe, et attulerunt, et suspenderunt contra Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And the people rejoiced exceedingly, and they spent that day in great joy.
verses.textLa: Et lætatus est populus valde, et egerunt diem illam in lætitia magna.

verses.textEn: And he established that this day should be kept every year, on the thirteenth day of the month of Adar.
verses.textLa: Et constituit agi omnibus annis diem istam tertiadecima die mensis Adar.

verses.textEn: And the land of Judah was quieted for a brief time.
verses.textLa: Et siluit terra Iuda dies paucos.

verses.textEn: And Judas heard of the fame of the Romans, that they are powerful and strong, and that they willingly agree to all things that are asked of them; and that, whoever was agreeable to them, they established a friendship with them, and so they are powerful and resourceful.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Iudas nomen Romanorum, quia sunt potentes viribus, et acquiescunt ad omnia, quæ postulantur ab eis: et quicumque accesserunt ad eos, statuerunt cum eis amicitias, et quia sunt potentes viribus.

verses.textEn: And they heard of their battles, and the successful works that they had accomplished in Galatia, how they had subdued them and brought them under tribute,
verses.textLa: Et audierunt prælia eorum, et virtutes bonas, quas fecerunt in Galatia, quia obtinuerunt eos, et duxerunt sub tributum:

verses.textEn: and what great things they had accomplished in the region of Spain, and that they had driven under their power the mines of silver and gold which are there, and that they had obtained possession of the entire place by their counsel and patience,
verses.textLa: et quanta fecerunt in regione Hispaniæ, et quod in potestatem redegerunt metalla argenti et auri, quæ illic sunt, et possederunt omnem locum consilio suo, et patientia:

verses.textEn: and that they had overcome places that were very far from them, and kings, who came against them from the ends of the earth, and had crushed them and struck them with a great scourging, while the rest pay tribute to them every year,
verses.textLa: locaque quæ longe erant valde ab eis, et reges, qui supervenerant eis ab extremis terræ, contriverunt, et percusserunt eos plaga magna: ceteri autem dant eis tributum omnibus annis:

verses.textEn: and that they had defeated in battle Philip, and Perses the king of the Ceteans, and the others who had taken up arms against them, and had crushed them in warfare and subdued them,
verses.textLa: et Philippum et Persen Ceteorum regem, et ceteros, qui adversum eos arma tulerant, contriverunt in bello, et obtinuerunt eos:
verses.notes: The word ‘ceteorum’ in Latin refers to sea creatures.

verses.textEn: and how Antiochus, the great king of Asia, who brought a fight against them, having one hundred and twenty elephants, with horsemen, and swift chariots, and a very great army, was crushed by them,
verses.textLa: et Antiochum magnum regem Asiæ, qui eis pugnam intulerat habens centum viginti elephantos, et equitatum, et currus, et exercitum magnum valde, contritum ab eis:

verses.textEn: and how they had captured him alive and had decreed to him that both he and those who would reign after him would pay a great tribute, and that he should provide hostages bound to an agreement,
verses.textLa: et quia ceperunt eum vivum, et statuerunt ei ut daret ipse, et qui regnarent post ipsum, tributum magnum, et daret obsides, et constitutum,

verses.textEn: and that regions from the Indians, and from the Medes, and from the Lydians, from among their best regions, with those whom they had taken from them, they gave to king Eumenes.
verses.textLa: et regionem Indorum, et Medos, et Lydos, de optimis regionibus eorum: et acceptas eas ab eis, dederunt Eumeni regi:

verses.textEn: And those who were in Greece wanted to go out and defeat them, but they became aware of this plan.
verses.textLa: et quia qui erant apud Helladam, voluerunt ire, et tollere eos: et innotuit sermo his,

verses.textEn: And so they sent one general to them, and he fought against them, and many of them fell, and they led into captivity their wives, and their sons, and they despoiled them and took possession of their land, and they destroyed their walls and drove them into servitude, even to this day.
verses.textLa: et miserunt ad eos ducem unum, et pugnaverunt contra illos, et ceciderunt ex eis multi, et captivas duxerunt uxores eorum, et filios, et diripuerunt eos, et terram eorum possederunt, et destruxerunt muros eorum, et in servitutem illos redegerunt usque in hunc diem:

verses.textEn: And the remaining kingdoms and islands, which at any time had resisted them, they destroyed and drove under their power.
verses.textLa: et residua regna, et insulas, quæ aliquando restiterant illis, exterminaverunt, et in potestatem redegerunt.

verses.textEn: But with their friends, and with those who remained at peace with them, they maintained friendship and conquered kingdoms: those that were near, and those that were far off. For all those who heard of their name were afraid of them.
verses.textLa: Cum amicis autem suis, et qui in ipsis requiem habebant, conservaverunt amicitiam, et obtinuerunt regna, quæ erant proxima, et quæ erant longe: quia quicumque audiebant nomen eorum, timebant eos:

verses.textEn: In fact, whomever they wanted to help become ruler, these reigned, but whomever they wanted, they deposed from the kingdom. And they were greatly exalted.
verses.textLa: quibus vero vellent auxilio esse ut regnarent, regnabant: quos autem vellent, regno deturbabant: et exaltati sunt valde.

verses.textEn: And of all these, none wore a diadem or was clothed in purple, to be magnified in this.
verses.textLa: Et in omnibus istis nemo portabat diadema, nec induebatur purpura, ut magnificaretur in ea.

verses.textEn: And also, they had made themselves a senate house, and they consulted daily with three hundred and twenty men, continually acting as a counsel for the multitude, so that they would do the things that were right.
verses.textLa: Et quia curiam fecerunt sibi, et quotidie consulebant trecentos viginti consilium agentes semper de multitudine, ut quæ digna sunt, gerant:

verses.textEn: And they commit their government to one man each year, to rule over their entire land, and they all obey this one, and there is no envy or jealousy among them.
verses.textLa: et committunt uni homini magistratum suum per singulos annos dominari universæ terræ suæ, et omnes obediunt uni, et non est invidia, neque zelus inter eos.

verses.textEn: And so Judas chose Eupolemus, the son of John, the son of Jacob, and Jason, the son of Eleazar, and he sent them to Rome to make an agreement of friendship and an alliance with them,
verses.textLa: Et elegit Iudas Eupolemum, filium Ioannis, filii Iacob, et Iasonem, filium Eleazari, et misit eos Romam constituere cum illis amicitiam, et societatem:

verses.textEn: and so that they would take away from them the yoke of the Grecians, for they saw that they oppressed the kingdom of Israel with servitude.
verses.textLa: et ut auferrent ab eis iugum Græcorum, quia viderunt quod in servitutem premerent regnum Israel.

verses.textEn: And they went to Rome, a very long journey, and they entered the senate house, and they said,
verses.textLa: Et abierunt Romam viam multam valde, et introierunt curiam, et dixerunt:

verses.textEn: “Judas Maccabeus, and his brothers, and the people of the Jews, have sent us to you to establish with you an alliance and peace, and so that we may be registered among your associates and friends.”
verses.textLa: Iudas Machabæus, et fratres eius, et populus Iudæorum miserunt nos ad vos statuere vobiscum societatem, et pacem, et conscribere nos socios et amicos vestros.

verses.textEn: And the word was pleasing in their sight.
verses.textLa: Et placuit sermo in conspectu eorum.

verses.textEn: And this is a copy of the writing, which they rewrote on tablets of brass and sent to Jerusalem, so that it would be with them in that place as a memorial of the peace and alliance:
verses.textLa: Et hoc rescriptum est, quod rescripserunt in tabulis æreis, et miserunt in Ierusalem, ut esset apud eos ibi memoriale pacis, et societatis.

verses.textEn: “May all be well with the Romans and with the nation of the Jews, at sea and on land, forever, and may sword and enemy be far away from them.
verses.textLa: BENE SIT ROMANIS, et genti Iudæorum in mari, et in terra in æternum: gladiusque et hostis procul sit ab eis.

verses.textEn: But if a war is instituted against the Romans first, or against any of their allies in all their dominions,
verses.textLa: Quod si institerit bellum Romanis prius, aut omnibus sociis eorum in omni dominatione eorum:

verses.textEn: the nation of the Jews will bring help to them, just as the situation shall direct, whole-heartedly.
verses.textLa: auxilium feret gens Iudæorum, prout tempus dictaverit, corde pleno:

verses.textEn: And those who do battle, they need not provide with supplies of wheat, or arms, or money, or ships, just as it seems good to the Romans, and they shall obey their orders, while taking nothing from them.
verses.textLa: et præliantibus non dabunt, neque subministrabunt triticum, arma, pecuniam, naves, sicut placuit Romanis: et custodient mandata eorum, nihil ab eis accipientes.
verses.notes: In other words, the Jews would not be mercenaries, taking goods or money in exchange for military support. Instead, they would fight for the Romans without even requiring food or weapons or other supports.

verses.textEn: But in like manner also, if war will have fallen upon the nation of the Jews first, the Romans shall help them willingly, just as the situation permits them.
verses.textLa: Similiter autem et si genti Iudæorum prius acciderit bellum, adiuvabunt Romani ex animo, prout eis tempus permiserit:
verses.notes: The expression ‘adiuvabunt ex animo’ refers to helping someone willingly, mind and soul.

verses.textEn: And those who give assistance will not be provided with wheat, or arms, or money, or ships, just as it seems good to the Romans. And they shall obey their orders without deceit.
verses.textLa: et adiuvantibus non dabitur triticum, arma, pecunia, naves, sicut placuit Romanis: et custodient mandata eorum absque dolo.

verses.textEn: According to these words, the Romans have made an agreement with the people of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Secundum hæc verba constituerunt Romani populo Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: And, if after these words, one or another would want to add anything to, or take anything from these, they may do as they propose. And whatever they add or take away, it shall be ratified.
verses.textLa: Quod si post hæc verba hi aut illi addere, aut demere ad hæc aliquid voluerint, facient ex proposito suo: et quæcumque addiderint, vel dempserint, rata erunt.

verses.textEn: Moreover, concerning the evils that king Demetrius did to them, we have written to him, saying, ‘Why have you made your yoke heavy upon our friends and allies, the Jews?
verses.textLa: Sed et de malis, quæ Demetrius rex fecit in eos, scripsimus ei, dicentes: Quare gravasti iugum tuum super amicos nostros, et socios Iudæos?

verses.textEn: If, therefore, they come again to us against you, we will render judgment for them, and we will make war against you by sea and by land.’ ”
verses.textLa: Si ergo iterum adierint nos, adversum te faciemus illis iudicium, et pugnabimus tecum mari terraque.

verses.textEn: Meanwhile, when Demetrius heard that Nicanor and his army had fallen in battle, he again positioned Bacchides and Alcimus in Judea, and the right horn of his army with them.
verses.textLa: Interea ut audivit Demetrius quia cecidit Nicanor, et exercitus eius in prælio, apposuit Bacchidem, et Alcimum rursum mittere in Iudæam, et dextrum cornu cum illis.

verses.textEn: And they traveled by the way that leads to Gilgal, and they set up camp in Mesaloth, which is in Arbela. And they occupied it, and they destroyed the lives of many men.
verses.textLa: Et abierunt viam, quæ ducit in Galgala, et castra posuerunt in Masaloth, quæ est in Arbellis: et occupaverunt eam, et peremerunt animas hominum multas.

verses.textEn: In the first month of the one hundred and fifty-second year, they positioned the army near Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: In mense primo anni centesimi et quinquagesimi secundi applicuerunt exercitum ad Ierusalem:

verses.textEn: And they rose up and went to Berea, with twenty thousand men and two thousand horsemen.
verses.textLa: et surrexerunt, et abierunt in Beream viginti millia virorum, et duo millia equitum.

verses.textEn: Now Judas had stationed his camp in Elasa, and three thousand chosen men were with him.
verses.textLa: Et Iudas posuerat castra in Laisa, et tria millia viri electi cum eo:

verses.textEn: And they saw the multitude of the army, that they were many, and they became very afraid. And many withdrew themselves from the camp, and there remained of them no more than eight hundred men.
verses.textLa: et viderunt multitudinem exercitus quia multi sunt, et timuerunt valde: et multi subtraxerunt se de castris, et non remanserunt ex eis nisi octingenti viri.

verses.textEn: And Judas saw that his army had slipped away and that the battle pressed upon him, and his heart was shattered, because he did not have time to gather them together, and he was very discouraged.
verses.textLa: Et vidit Iudas quod defluxit exercitus suus, et bellum perurgebat eum, et confractus est corde: quia non habebat tempus congregandi eos, et dissolutus est.

verses.textEn: And so, he said to those who were remaining, “Let us rise up and go against our enemies, perhaps we may be able to fight against them.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit his, qui residui erant: Surgamus, et eamus ad adversarios nostros, si poterimus pugnare adversus eos.

verses.textEn: But they dissuaded him, saying: “We will not be able, but let us try to save our lives and return to our brothers, and then we will fight against them. For we are but few.”
verses.textLa: Et avertebant eum, dicentes: Non poterimus, sed liberemus animas nostras modo, et revertamur ad fratres nostros, et tunc pugnabimus adversus eos: nos autem pauci sumus.

verses.textEn: And Judas said: “Far be it from us, to do this thing, so as to flee away from them. But if our time has drawn near, let us die with virtue, on behalf of our brothers, and let us not inflict guilt upon our glory.”
verses.textLa: Et ait Iudas: Absit istam rem facere ut fugiamus ab eis: et si appropiavit tempus nostrum, moriamur in virtute propter fratres nostros, et non inferamus crimen gloriæ nostræ.

verses.textEn: And the army moved from the camp, and they stood to meet them. And the horsemen were divided into two parts, and the stone-slingers and archers went before the army, and the first ones were all powerful men, experienced in combat.
verses.textLa: Et movit exercitus de castris, et steterunt illis obviam: et divisi sunt equites in duas partes, et fundibularii, et sagittarii præibant exercitum, et primi certaminis omnes potentes.
verses.notes: The word ‘certaminis’ refers to those strong men, ‘potentes,’ who had been tested by battle, in other words, veterans, experienced in combat.

verses.textEn: Moreover, Bacchides was with the right horn, and the legion drew near on both sides, and they sounded the trumpets.
verses.textLa: Bacchides autem erat in dextro cornu, et proximavit legio ex duabus partibus, et clamabant tubis:

verses.textEn: But those also who were from the side of Judas, these also now cried out, and the earth shook at the noise of the armies. And the battle was joined from morning, even until evening.
verses.textLa: exclamaverunt autem et hi, qui erant ex parte Iudæ, etiam ipsi, et commota est terra a voce exercituum: et commissum est prælium a mane usque ad vesperam.

verses.textEn: And Judas saw that the stronger part of the army of Bacchides was on the right side, and all the steadfast in heart came together with him.
verses.textLa: Et vidit Iudas, quod firmior est pars exercitus Bacchidis in dextris, et convenerunt cum ipso omnes constantes corde:

verses.textEn: And the right part was crushed by them, and he pursued them even to Mount Azotus.
verses.textLa: et contrita est dextera pars ab eis, et persecutus est eos usque ad montem Azoti.

verses.textEn: And those who were with the left horn saw that the right horn was crushed, and so they followed after Judas, and those who were with him, at their back.
verses.textLa: Et qui in sinistro cornu erant, viderunt quod contritum est dextrum cornu, et secuti sunt post Iudam, et eos, qui cum ipso erant, a tergo:

verses.textEn: And the battle was hard fought, and there fell many wounded from one side and the other.
verses.textLa: et ingravatum est prælium, et ceciderunt vulnerati multi ex his, et ex illis.

verses.textEn: And Judas fell, and the others fled away.
verses.textLa: Et Iudas cecidit, et ceteri fugerunt.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan and Simon carried Judas, their brother, and they buried him in the sepulcher of their fathers, in the city of Modin.
verses.textLa: Et Ionathas, et Simon tulerunt Iudam fratrem suum, et sepelierunt eum in sepulchro patrum suorum in civitate Modin.

verses.textEn: And all the people of Israel wept for him with a great wailing, and they mourned him for many days.
verses.textLa: Et fleverunt eum omnis populus Israel planctu magno, et lugebant dies multos,

verses.textEn: And they said, “Such a powerful man has fallen, who accomplished the salvation of the people of Israel!”
verses.textLa: et dixerunt: Quomodo cecidit potens, qui salvum faciebat populum Israel!

verses.textEn: But the rest of the words, about the wars of Judas, and the virtuous acts that he did, and his magnitude, have not been written. For they were very many.
verses.textLa: Et cetera verba bellorum Iudæ, et virtutum, quas fecit, et magnitudinis eius, non sunt descripta: multa enim erant valde.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, after the death of Judas, the iniquitous began to emerge in all the parts of Israel, and they began to encourage all those who worked iniquity.
verses.textLa: Et factum est: post obitum Iudæ emerserunt iniqui in omnibus finibus Israel, et exorti sunt omnes, qui operabantur iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: In those days, there occurred a very great famine, and the entire region handed itself over to Bacchides.
verses.textLa: In diebus illis facta est fames magna valde, et tradidit se Bacchidi omnis regio eorum cum ipsis.

verses.textEn: And Bacchides chose impious men, and he appointed them as rulers of the region.
verses.textLa: Et elegit Bacchides viros impios, et constituit eos dominos regionis:

verses.textEn: And they sought out and persecuted the friends of Judas, and they led them to Bacchides, and he took vengeance on them and abused them.
verses.textLa: et exquirebant, et perscrutabantur amicos Iudæ, et adducebant eos ad Bacchidem, et vindicabat in illos, et illudebat.

verses.textEn: And there occurred a great tribulation in Israel, such as had never been, since the day that there was no prophet seen in Israel.
verses.textLa: Et facta est tribulatio magna in Israel, qualis non fuit ex die, qua non est visus propheta in Israel.

verses.textEn: And all the friends of Judas gathered together, and they said to Jonathan:
verses.textLa: Et congregati sunt omnes amici Iudæ, et dixerunt Ionathæ:

verses.textEn: “Since your brother Judas has fallen away, there is not a man like him to go forth against our enemies, against Bacchides and those who are the enemies of our nation.
verses.textLa: Ex quo frater tuus Iudas defunctus est, vir similis ei non est, qui exeat contra inimicos nostros, Bacchidem, et eos, qui inimici sunt gentis nostræ.

verses.textEn: And so now, we have chosen you in his place, on this day, to be our leader and commander in order to wage our wars.”
verses.textLa: Nunc itaque te hodie elegimus esse pro eo nobis in principem, et ducem ad bellandum bellum nostrum.

verses.textEn: And so, at that time, Jonathan took upon himself the leadership, and he rose up in the place of Judas, his brother.
verses.textLa: Et suscepit Ionathas tempore illo principatum, et surrexit loco Iudæ fratris sui.

verses.textEn: And Bacchides knew of it, and he sought to kill him.
verses.textLa: Et cognovit Bacchides, et quærebat eum occidere.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan and his brother Simon knew of this, and so did all who were with them. And they fled into the desert of Tekoa, and they settled by the water of lake Asphar.
verses.textLa: Et cognovit Ionathas, et Simon frater eius, et omnes, qui cum eo erant: et fugerunt in desertum Thecuæ, et consederunt ad aquam lacus Asphar.

verses.textEn: And Bacchides knew of it, and on the day of the Sabbath, he himself arrived, with all his army, across the Jordan.
verses.textLa: Et cognovit Bacchides, et die Sabbatorum venit ipse, et omnis exercitus eius trans Iordanem.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan sent his brother, a commander of the people, to ask the Nabateans, his friends, to lend them their equipment, which was abundant.
verses.textLa: Et Ionathas misit fratrem suum ducem populi, et rogavit Nabuthæos amicos suos, ut commodarent illis apparatum suum, qui erat copiosus.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Jambri went forth from Medeba, and they captured John, and all that he had, and they went away in possession of these.
verses.textLa: Et exierunt filii Iambri ex Madaba, et comprehenderunt Ioannem, et omnia, quæ habebat, et abierunt habentes ea.

verses.textEn: After these events, it was reported to Jonathan and his brother Simon that the sons of Jambri were having a great marriage celebration, and that they would be leading the bride, a daughter of one of the great leaders of Canaan, out of Medeba with great fanfare.
verses.textLa: Post hæc verba, renunciatum est Ionathæ, et Simoni fratri eius, quia filii Iambri faciunt nuptias magnas, et ducunt sponsam ex Madaba filiam unius de magnis principibus Chanaan cum ambitione magna.

verses.textEn: And they remembered the blood of John, their brother. And they went up and hid themselves under the cover of the mountain.
verses.textLa: Et recordati sunt sanguinis Ioannis fratris sui: et ascenderunt, et absconderunt se sub tegumento montis.

verses.textEn: And they lifted up their eyes and saw. And behold, a tumult and a well-prepared multitude. And the bridegroom proceeded, with his friends and his brothers, to meet them with timbrels, and musical instruments, and many weapons.
verses.textLa: Et elevaverunt oculos suos, et viderunt: et ecce tumultus, et apparatus multus: et sponsus processit, et amici eius, et fratres eius obviam illis cum tympanis, et musicis, et armis multis.

verses.textEn: And they rose up against them out of ambush, and they killed them, and there fell many wounded, and the remainder fled into the mountains, and they took all their spoils.
verses.textLa: Et surrexerunt ad eos ex insidiis, et occiderunt eos, et ceciderunt vulnerati multi, et residui fugerunt in montes: et acceperunt omnia spolia eorum:

verses.textEn: And the marriage celebration was turned into mourning, and the voice of their musical instruments into lamentation.
verses.textLa: et conversæ sunt nuptiæ in luctum, et vox musicorum ipsorum in lamentum.

verses.textEn: And they took revenge for the blood of their brother, and they returned to the bank of the Jordan.
verses.textLa: Et vindicaverunt vindictam sanguinis fratris sui: et reversi sunt ad ripam Iordanis.

verses.textEn: And Bacchides heard about this, and he came on the day of the Sabbath all the way to the coast of the Jordan, with a great force.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Bacchides, et venit die Sabbatorum usque ad oram Iordanis in virtute magna.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan said to his own: “Let us rise up and fight against our enemies. For it is not today, as it was yesterday, or the day before.
verses.textLa: Et dixit ad suos Ionathas: Surgamus, et pugnemus contra inimicos nostros: non est enim hodie sicut heri, et nudiustertius.

verses.textEn: For behold, the war is before us, and truly, with the water of the Jordan here and there, and the banks, and the marshes, and the woods: there is no place for us to turn aside.
verses.textLa: Ecce enim bellum ex adverso, aqua vero Iordanis hinc et inde, et ripæ, et paludes, et saltus: et non est locus divertendi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, cry out now to heaven so that you may be freed from the hand of your enemies.” And they joined together in warfare.
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo clamate in cælum, ut liberemini de manu inimicorum vestrorum. Et commissum est bellum.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan extended his hand to strike Bacchides, but he turned away from him in retreat.
verses.textLa: Et extendit Ionathas manum suam percutere Bacchidem, et divertit ab eo retro:

verses.textEn: And Jonathan, and those who were with him, leaped forward into the Jordan, and they swam across the Jordan to them.
verses.textLa: et desiliit Ionathas, et qui cum eo erant in Iordanem, et transnataverunt ad eos Iordanem.

verses.textEn: And there fell from the side of Bacchides on that day one thousand men. And they returned to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et ceciderunt de parte Bacchidis die illa mille viri: et reversi sunt in Ierusalem,

verses.textEn: And they built fortified cities in Judea: the fortification that was in Jericho, and in Emmaus, and in Bethhoron, and in Bethel, and Timnath, and Pharathon, and Tephon, with high walls, and gates, and bars.
verses.textLa: et ædificaverunt civitates munitas in Iudæa, munitionem, quæ erat in Iericho, et in Ammaum, et in Bethoron, et in Bethel, et Thamnata, et Phara, et Thopo muris excelsis, et portis, et seris.

verses.textEn: And he stationed garrisons in them, so that those in Israel became trained in warfare.
verses.textLa: Et posuit custodiam in eis, ut inimicitias exercerent in Israel:

verses.textEn: And he fortified the city of Bethzur, and of Gazara, and the stronghold, and he stationed auxiliaries in them, with supplies of rations.
verses.textLa: et munivit civitatem Bethsuram, et Gazaram, et arcem, et posuit in eis auxilia, et apparatum escarum:

verses.textEn: And he took the sons of the leaders of the region for hostages, and put them in the stronghold in Jerusalem under guard.
verses.textLa: et accepit filios principum regionis obsides, et posuit eos in arce in Ierusalem in custodiam.

verses.textEn: Now in the second month of the one hundred and fifty-third year, Alcimus instructed that the walls of the inner court of the sanctuary be destroyed, and that the works of the prophets be destroyed. And he began to destroy them.
verses.textLa: Et anno centesimo quinquagesimo tertio, mense secundo, præcepit Alcimus destrui muros domus sanctæ interioris, et destrui opera prophetarum: et cœpit destruere.

verses.textEn: At that time, Alcimus was struck, and his works were hindered, and his mouth was closed shut, and he was weakened with paralysis, so that he was no longer able speak a word, nor to give orders concerning his house.
verses.textLa: In tempore illo percussus est Alcimus: et impedita sunt opera illius, et occlusum est os eius, et dissolutus est paralysi, nec ultra potuit loqui verbum, et mandare de domo sua.

verses.textEn: And Alcimus died at that time, in great torment.
verses.textLa: Et mortuus est Alcimus in tempore illo cum tormento magno.
verses.notes: The antipope during the reign of the Antichrist will fall ill and die, in great torment, struck down by the hand of God.

verses.textEn: And Bacchides saw that Alcimus was dead. And he returned to the king. And the land was quiet for two years.
verses.textLa: Et vidit Bacchides quoniam mortuus est Alcimus: et reversus est ad regem. Et siluit terra annis duobus.

verses.textEn: And all the iniquitous considered together, saying, “Behold, Jonathan, and those who are with him, live in quietude and confidence. Now, therefore, let us bring forth Bacchides, and he will capture them all, in one night.”
verses.textLa: Et cogitaverunt omnes iniqui dicentes: Ecce Ionathas, et qui cum eo sunt, in silentio habitant confidenter: nunc ergo adducamus Bacchidem, et comprehendet eos omnes una nocte.

verses.textEn: So they went and gave counsel to him.
verses.textLa: Et abierunt, et consilium ei dederunt.

verses.textEn: And he rose up, so as to advance with a great army. And he secretly sent letters to his associates who were in Judea, to seize Jonathan and those who were with him. But they were not able, for their plan became known to them.
verses.textLa: Et surrexit ut veniret cum exercitu multo: et misit occulte epistolas sociis suis, qui erant in Iudæa, ut comprehenderent Ionathan, et eos, qui cum eo erant: sed non potuerunt, quia innotuit eis consilium eorum.

verses.textEn: And he apprehended, from the men of the region, those who were the leaders of this malice, fifty men. And he killed them.
verses.textLa: Et apprehendit de viris regionis, qui principes erant malitiæ, quinquaginta viros, et occidit eos:

verses.textEn: And Jonathan, and Simon, and those who were with him, withdrew into Bethbasi, which is in the desert. And he repaired its breaches, and they fortified it.
verses.textLa: et secessit Ionathas, et Simon, et qui cum eo erant in Bethbessen, quæ est in deserto: et extruxit diruta eius, et firmaverunt eam.

verses.textEn: And Bacchides knew about it, and he gathered together all his multitude. And he reported it to those who were from Judea.
verses.textLa: Et cognovit Bacchides, et congregavit universam multitudinem suam: et his, qui de Iudæa erant, denunciavit.

verses.textEn: And he came and made camp above Bethbasi, and he fought against it for many days, and he made machines of war.
verses.textLa: Et venit, et castra posuit desuper Bethbessen: et oppugnavit eam dies multos, et fecit machinas.

verses.textEn: But Jonathan left behind his brother Simon in the city, and he went out into the country, and he approached with a number of men,
verses.textLa: Et reliquit Ionathas Simonem fratrem suum in civitate, et exiit in regionem, et venit cum numero,

verses.textEn: and he struck Odomera and his brothers, and the sons of Phasiron, in their tents. And he began to slaughter and to increase in forces.
verses.textLa: et percussit Odaren, et fratres eius, et filios Phaseron in tabernaculis ipsorum: et cœpit cædere, et crescere in virtutibus.

verses.textEn: In truth, Simon, and those who were with him, went forth from the city and burned the machines of war,
