verses.textLa: Simon vero, et qui cum ipso erant, exierunt de civitate, et succenderunt machinas,

verses.textEn: and they fought against Bacchides, and he was crushed by them. And they afflicted him greatly, because his counsel and his meetings were in vain.
verses.textLa: et pugnaverunt contra Bacchidem, et contritus est ab eis: et afflixerunt eum valde, quoniam consilium eius, et congressus eius erat inanis.

verses.textEn: And he was angry with the men of iniquity who had given him counsel to come into their region, and he killed many of them. But he decided to depart with the remainder into their country.
verses.textLa: Et iratus contra viros iniquos, qui ei consilium dederant ut veniret in regionem ipsorum, multos ex eis occidit: ipse autem cogitavit cum reliquis abire in regionem suam.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan knew of it, and he sent ambassadors to him to arrange a peace with him, and to restore the captives to him.
verses.textLa: Et cognovit Ionathas: et misit ad eum legatos componere pacem cum ipso, et reddere ei captivitatem.

verses.textEn: And he accepted it willingly, and he acted according to his words, and he swore that he would do him no evil all the days of his life.
verses.textLa: Et libenter accepit, et fecit secundum verba eius, et iuravit se nihil facturum ei mali omnibus diebus vitæ eius.

verses.textEn: And he restored to him the captives which he previously had been given from the land of Judah. And he turned back and went away into his own land, and he no longer drew near, in order to enter into their borders.
verses.textLa: Et reddidit ei captivitatem, quam prius erat prædatus de terra Iuda: et conversus abiit in terram suam, et non apposuit amplius venire in fines eius:

verses.textEn: And so the sword ceased from Israel. And Jonathan lived in Michmash, and, in that place, Jonathan began to judge the people, and he destroyed the impious out of Israel.
verses.textLa: Et cessavit gladius ex Israel: et habitavit Ionathas in Machmas, et cœpit Ionathas ibi iudicare populum, et exterminavit impios ex Israel.

verses.textEn: And in the one hundred and sixtieth year, Alexander, the son of Antiochus, who was surnamed the illustrious, came up and occupied Ptolemais, and they received him, and he reigned there.
verses.textLa: Et anno centesimo sexagesimo ascendit Alexander Antiochi filius, qui cognominatus est Nobilis: et occupavit Ptolemaidam: et receperunt eum, et regnavit illic.

verses.textEn: And king Demetrius heard of it, and he gathered together an exceedingly great army, and he went forth to meet him in battle.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Demetrius rex, et congregavit exercitum copiosum valde, et exivit obviam illi in prælium.

verses.textEn: And Demetrius sent a letter to Jonathan, with peaceful words, to magnify him.
verses.textLa: Et misit Demetrius epistolam ad Ionathan verbis pacificis, ut magnificaret eum.

verses.textEn: For he said, “Let us first make a peace with him, before he makes one with Alexander against us.
verses.textLa: Dixit enim: Anticipemus facere pacem cum eo, priusquam faciat cum Alexandro adversum nos.

verses.textEn: For he will remember all the evils that we have done to him, and to his brother, and to his nation.”
verses.textLa: Recordabitur enim omnium malorum, quæ fecimus in eum, et in fratrem eius, et in gentem eius.

verses.textEn: And he gave him the authority to gather together an army, and to fabricate weapons, so that he would be his associate. And the hostages who were in the stronghold, he ordered to be handed over to him.
verses.textLa: Et dedit ei potestatem congregandi exercitum, et fabricare arma, et esse ipsum socium eius: et obsides, qui erant in arce, iussit tradi ei.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan came to Jerusalem, and he read the letters in the hearing of all the people and of those who were in the stronghold.
verses.textLa: Et venit Ionathas in Ierusalem, et legit epistolas in auditu omnis populi, et eorum, qui in arce erant.

verses.textEn: And they were struck with a great fear, because they heard that the king gave him the authority to gather together an army.
verses.textLa: Et timuerunt timore magno, quoniam audierunt quod dedit ei rex potestatem congregandi exercitum.

verses.textEn: And the hostages were handed over to Jonathan, and he restored them to their parents.
verses.textLa: Et traditi sunt Ionathæ obsides, et reddidit eos parentibus suis:

verses.textEn: And Jonathan lived in Jerusalem, and he began to rebuild and repair the city.
verses.textLa: et habitavit Ionathas in Ierusalem, et cœpit ædificare, et innovare civitatem.

verses.textEn: And he told those doing the work to build up the walls, and mount Zion, all around, with square stones, as a fortification. And they did so.
verses.textLa: Et dixit facientibus opera ut extruerent muros, et montem Sion in circuitu lapidibus quadratis ad munitionem: et ita fecerunt.

verses.textEn: Then the foreigners, who were in the fortifications that Bacchides had built, fled away.
verses.textLa: Et fugerunt alienigenæ, qui erant in munitionibus, quas Bacchides ædificaverat:

verses.textEn: And each one abandoned his place and departed into his own land.
verses.textLa: et reliquit unusquisque locum suum, et abiit in terram suam:

verses.textEn: Only in Bethzur did there remain some others of these, who had forsaken the law and the precepts of God. For this was a refuge for them.
verses.textLa: tantum in Bethsura remanserunt aliqui ex his, qui reliquerant legem, et præcepta Dei. Erat enim hæc eis ad refugium.

verses.textEn: And king Alexander heard of the promises that Demetrius promised to Jonathan. And they described the battles to him, and the virtuous deeds that he and his brothers had done, and the hardships that they had endured.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Alexander rex promissa, quæ promisit Demetrius Ionathæ: et narraverunt ei prælia, et virtutes, quas ipse fecit, et fratres eius, et labores, quos laboraverunt.

verses.textEn: And he said: “Would we ever find another such man? And so now, let us make him our friend and our associate.”
verses.textLa: Et ait: Numquid inveniemus aliquem virum talem? et nunc faciemus eum amicum, et socium nostrum.

verses.textEn: And so, he wrote a letter, and he sent it to him, according to these words, saying:
verses.textLa: Et scripsit epistolam, et misit ei secundum hæc verba, dicens:

verses.textEn: “King Alexander to his brother, Jonathan: greetings.
verses.textLa: REX Alexander fratri Ionathæ salutem.

verses.textEn: We have heard of you, that you are a man of power and strength, and that you are fit to be our friend.
verses.textLa: Audivimus de te quod vir potens sis viribus, et aptus es ut sis amicus noster:

verses.textEn: And so now, on this day, we appoint that you be high priest of your people, and that you be called the king’s friend, (and he sent him a purple robe, and a crown of gold,) and that you be of one mind with us in our affairs, and that you keep friendship with us.”
verses.textLa: et nunc constituimus te hodie summum sacerdotem gentis tuæ, et ut amicus voceris regis, (et misit ei purpuram, et coronam auream) et quæ nostra sunt sentias nobiscum, et conserves amicitias ad nos.

verses.textEn: Then Jonathan clothed himself with the holy vestment, in the seventh month, in the one hundred and sixtieth year, on the solemn day of the Feast of Tabernacles. And he gathered together an army, and he made an abundance of weapons.
verses.textLa: Et induit se Ionathas stola sancta septimo mense, anno centesimo sexagesimo in die sollemni scenopegiæ: et congregavit exercitum, et fecit arma copiosa.

verses.textEn: And Demetrius heard these words, and he was exceedingly sorrowful, and he said:
verses.textLa: Et audivit Demetrius verba ista, et contristatus est nimis, et ait:

verses.textEn: “What have we done in this, that Alexander has gone before us to obtain the friendship of the Jews to strengthen himself?
verses.textLa: Quid hoc fecimus, quod præoccupavit nos Alexander apprehendere amicitiam Iudæorum ad munimen sui?

verses.textEn: I also will write to them words of petition, and offer positions of rank and gifts, so that they may act in assistance to me.”
verses.textLa: Scribam et ego illis verba deprecatoria, et dignitates, et dona: ut sint mecum in adiutorium.

verses.textEn: And he wrote to them in these words: “King Demetrius to the nation of the Jews: greetings.
verses.textLa: Et scripsit eis in hæc verba: Rex Demetrius genti Iudæorum salutem:

verses.textEn: Since you have kept the peace with us, and have remained in our friendship, and have not made agreements with our enemies, we have heard of this, and we are glad.
verses.textLa: Quoniam servastis ad nos pactum, et mansistis in amicitia nostra, et non accessistis ad inimicos nostros, audivimus, et gavisi sumus.

verses.textEn: And so now, persevere still to remain faithful to us, and we will reward you with good things for what you have done for us.
verses.textLa: Et nunc perseverate adhuc conservare ad nos fidem, et retribuemus vobis bona pro his, quæ fecistis nobiscum:

verses.textEn: And we will repay you for your many expenses, and we will give you gifts.
verses.textLa: et remittemus vobis præstationes multas, et dabimus vobis donationes.

verses.textEn: And now, I release you, and all the Jews, from tributes, and I grant to you the payments of salt, and I send back the crowns and the thirds of the seed.
verses.textLa: Et nunc absolvo vos, et omnes Iudæos a tributis, et pretia salis indulgeo, et coronas remitto, et tertias seminis:

verses.textEn: And the one half portion of the fruit from the trees, which is my share, I relinquish to you from this day and hereafter, so that it shall not be taken from the land of Judah, nor from the three cities that have been added to it from Samaria and Galilee, from this day and for all time.
verses.textLa: et dimidiam partem fructus ligni, quod est portionis meæ, relinquo vobis ex hodierno die, et deinceps, ne accipiatur a terra Iuda, et a tribus civitatibus, quæ additæ sunt illi ex Samaria, et Galilæa ex hodierna die et in totum tempus:

verses.textEn: And let Jerusalem be holy and free within its borders, and let the tenths and tributes be for itself.
verses.textLa: et Ierusalem sit sancta, et libera cum finibus suis: et decimæ, et tributa ipsius sint.

verses.textEn: And I even return authority over the stronghold, which is in Jerusalem, and I give it to the high priest, in order to appoint in it any such men as he will choose, who will guard it.
verses.textLa: Remitto etiam potestatem arcis, quæ est in Ierusalem: et do eam summo sacerdoti, ut constituat in ea viros quoscumque ipse elegerit, qui custodiant eam.

verses.textEn: And every soul of the Jews who were taken captive from the land of Judah in all my kingdom, I set at liberty without charge, so that they are all released from tributes, even of their cattle.
verses.textLa: Et omnem animam Iudæorum, quæ captiva est a terra Iuda in omni regno meo, relinquo liberam gratis, ut omnes a tributis solvantur, etiam pecorum suorum.

verses.textEn: And all the days of solemnities, and the Sabbaths, and the new moons, and the decreed days, and the three days before the solemn day, and three days after the solemn day, shall all be days of immunity and remission for all the Jews who are in my kingdom.
verses.textLa: Et omnes dies sollemnes, et Sabbata, et neomeniæ, et dies decreti, et tres dies ante diem solemnem, et tres dies post diem sollemnem sint omnes immunitatis et remissionis omnibus Iudæis, qui sunt in regno meo:

verses.textEn: And no one will have the authority to do anything, or to incite any plots, against any of them, in all cases.
verses.textLa: et nemo habebit potestatem agere aliquid, et movere negotia adversus aliquem illorum in omni causa.

verses.textEn: And let there be enrolled from the Jews, into the army of the king, up to thirty thousand men. And allowances shall be given to them, just as is due to all the king’s army. And some of them shall be appointed to be in the fortresses of the great king.
verses.textLa: Et ascribantur ex Iudæis in exercitu regis ad triginta millia virorum: et dabuntur illis copiæ ut oportet omnibus exercitibus regis, et ex eis ordinabuntur qui sint in munitionibus regis magni:

verses.textEn: And some of them shall be set over the affairs of the kingdom, those who act with faith, and let the leaders be from them, and let them walk by their own laws, just as the king has commanded in the land of Judah.
verses.textLa: et ex his constituentur super negotia regni, quæ aguntur ex fide, et principes sint ex eis, et ambulent in legibus suis, sicut præcepit rex in terra Iuda.

verses.textEn: And the three cities that have been added to Judea from the region of Samaria, let them be counted with Judea, so that they may be united as one, and so that they may obey no other authority, except the high priest.
verses.textLa: Et tres civitates, quæ additæ sunt Iudææ ex regione Samariæ, cum Iudæa reputentur: ut sint sub uno, et non obediant alii potestati, nisi summi sacerdotis:

verses.textEn: Ptolemais and its confines, I give as a free gift to the holy places that are in Jerusalem, for the necessary expenses of the holy things.
verses.textLa: Ptolemaida, et confines eius, quas dedi donum sanctis, qui sunt in Ierusalem ad necessarios sumptus sanctorum.

verses.textEn: And I give, every year, fifteen thousand shekels of silver from the allotment of the king, from what belongs to me.
verses.textLa: Et ego do singulis annis quindecim millia siclorum argenti de rationibus regis, quæ me contingunt:

verses.textEn: And all that has been left over, which those who were set over the affairs in prior years have not paid: from this time, they will give it to the works of the house.
verses.textLa: et omne, quod reliquum fuerit, quod non reddiderant qui super negotia erant annis prioribus, ex hoc dabunt in opera domus.

verses.textEn: And beyond this, they shall receive five thousand shekels of silver from the allotment of the holy places each year, and this will belong to the priests who perform the ministry.
verses.textLa: Et super hæc quinque millia siclorum argenti, quæ accipiebant de sanctorum ratione per singulos annos: et hæc ad sacerdotes pertineant, qui ministerio funguntur.

verses.textEn: And whoever will flee into the temple that is in Jerusalem, or in any of its parts, being liable before the king in any matter, let them be released, and all that is theirs in my kingdom, let them have it freely.
verses.textLa: Et quicumque confugerint in templum, quod est Ierosolymis, et in omnibus finibus eius, obnoxii regi in omni negotio dimittantur, et universa, quæ sunt eis in regno meo, libera habeant.

verses.textEn: And as to the works of rebuilding and repairing the holy places, the expenses shall be given from the king’s revenues.
verses.textLa: Et ad ædificanda vel restauranda opera sanctorum, sumptus dabuntur de ratione regis:

verses.textEn: And as to the raising of the walls of Jerusalem and the fortifications all around it, the expenses shall be given from the king’s revenues, as also for the building of the walls in Judea.”
verses.textLa: et ad extruendos muros Ierusalem, et communiendos in circuitu, sumptus dabuntur de ratione regis, et ad construendos muros in Iudæa.

verses.textEn: So when Jonathan and the people heard these words, they did not believe or accept them, because they remembered the great malice that he had done in Israel, for he had troubled them greatly.
verses.textLa: Ut audivit autem Ionathas, et populus sermones istos, non crediderunt eis, nec receperunt eos: quia recordati sunt malitiæ magnæ, quam fecerat in Israel, et tribulaverat eos valde.

verses.textEn: And so they were pleased with Alexander, because he had been to them a leader with words of peace, and they were of assistance to him every day.
verses.textLa: Et complacuit eis in Alexandrum, quia ipse fuerat eis princeps sermonum pacis, et ipsi auxilium ferebant omnibus diebus.

verses.textEn: And so king Alexander gathered together a great army, and he moved his camp against Demetrius.
verses.textLa: Et congregavit rex Alexander exercitum magnum, et admovit castra contra Demetrium.

verses.textEn: And the two kings joined together in battle, and the army of Demetrius fled away, and Alexander followed after him, and he closed in on them.
verses.textLa: Et commiserunt prælium duo reges, et fugit exercitus Demetrii, et insecutus est eum Alexander, et incubuit super eos.

verses.textEn: And the battle was hard fought, until the sun went down. And Demetrius was slain on that day.
verses.textLa: Et invaluit prælium nimis, donec occidit sol: et cecidit Demetrius in die illa.

verses.textEn: And Alexander sent ambassadors to Ptolemy, the king of Egypt, according to these words, saying:
verses.textLa: Et misit Alexander ad Ptolemæum regem Ægypti legatos secundum hæc verba, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Know that I have returned to my kingdom, and I am seated upon the throne of my fathers, and I have obtained the leadership, and I have crushed Demetrius, and I have taken possession of our country,
verses.textLa: QUONIAM regressus sum in regnum meum, et sedi in sede patrum meorum, et obtinui principatum, et contrivi Demetrium, et possedi regionem nostram,

verses.textEn: and I have joined battle with him, and both he and his camp have been crushed by us, and we are seated on the throne of his kingdom.
verses.textLa: et commisi pugnam cum eo, et contritus est ipse, et castra eius a nobis, et sedimus in sede regni eius:

verses.textEn: And now, let us establish a friendship with one with another. And give me your daughter as a wife, and I will be your son-in-law, and I will give gifts that are worthy of you, to both you and her.”
verses.textLa: et nunc statuamus ad invicem amicitiam: et da mihi filiam tuam uxorem, et ego ero gener tuus, et dabo tibi dona, et ipsi digna te.

verses.textEn: And king Ptolemy responded by saying: “Happy is the day on which you were returned to the land of your fathers, and you sat on the throne of their kingdom.
verses.textLa: Et respondit rex Ptolemæus, dicens: FELIX dies, in qua reversus es ad terram patrum tuorum, et sedisti in sede regni eorum.

verses.textEn: And now, I will do for you as you have written. But meet with me at Ptolemais, so that we may see one another, and so that I may espouse her to you, just as you have said.”
verses.textLa: Et nunc faciam tibi quod scripsisti: sed occurre mihi Ptolemaidam, ut videamus invicem nos, et spondeam tibi sicut dixisti.

verses.textEn: And so Ptolemy departed from Egypt, both he and his daughter Cleopatra, and he arrived at Ptolemais in the one hundred and sixty-second year.
verses.textLa: Et exivit Ptolemæus de Ægypto, ipse et Cleopatra filia eius, et venit Ptolemaidam anno centesimo sexagesimo secundo.

verses.textEn: And king Alexander met him, and he gave him Cleopatra, his daughter. And he celebrated her marriage at Ptolemais with great glory, just as befits kings.
verses.textLa: Et occurrit ei Alexander rex, et dedit ei Cleopatram filiam suam: et fecit nuntias eius Ptolemaidæ, sicut reges, in magna gloria.

verses.textEn: And king Alexander wrote to Jonathan, that he should come to meet him.
verses.textLa: Et scripsit rex Alexander Ionathæ, ut veniret obviam sibi.

verses.textEn: And he went forth with glory to Ptolemais, and he met the two kings there, and he gave them much silver, and gold, and gifts. And he found favor in their sight.
verses.textLa: Et abiit cum gloria Ptolemaidam, et occurrit ibi duobus regibus, et dedit illis argentum multum, et aurum, et dona: et invenit gratiam in conspectu eorum.

verses.textEn: And some of the pestilent men of Israel, men of iniquity, came together against him, interrupting with objections against him. And the king did not attend to them.
verses.textLa: Et convenerunt adversus eum viri pestilentes ex Israel, viri iniqui interpellantes adversus eum: et non intendit ad eos rex.

verses.textEn: And he ordered that Jonathan’s garments be taken away from him, and that he be clothed in purple. And they did so. And the king arranged for him to sit with him.
verses.textLa: Et iussit spoliari Ionathan vestibus suis, et indui eum purpura: et ita fecerunt. Et collocavit eum rex sedere secum.

verses.textEn: And he said to his princes, “Go out with him into the midst of the city, and make a proclamation, so that no one may raise objections against him in any matter, and so that no one may bother him for any reason.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque principibus suis: Exite cum eo in medium civitatis, et prædicate, ut nemo adversus eum interpellet de ullo negotio, nec quisquam ei molestus sit de ulla ratione.

verses.textEn: And so it happened that, when his accusers saw his glory being proclaimed, and him clothed in purple, they all fled away.
verses.textLa: Et factum est, ut viderunt qui interpellabant gloriam eius, quæ prædicabatur, et opertum eum purpura, fugerunt omnes:

verses.textEn: And the king magnified him, and he enrolled him among his foremost friends, and he gave him a position as governor and as a participant in his dominion.
verses.textLa: et magnificavit eum rex, et scripsit eum inter primos amicos, et posuit eum ducem, et participem principatus.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan returned to Jerusalem with peace and joy.
verses.textLa: Et reversus est Ionathas in Ierusalem cum pace, et lætitia.

verses.textEn: In the one hundred and sixty-fifth year, Demetrius, the son of Demetrius, came from Crete into the land of his fathers.
verses.textLa: In anno centesimo sexagesimoquinto venit Demetrius filius Demetrii a Creta in terram patrum suorum.

verses.textEn: And king Alexander heard of it, and he was very sorrowful, and he returned to Antioch.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Alexander rex, et contristatus est valde, et reversus est Antiochum.

verses.textEn: And king Demetrius appointed Apollonius as his general, who was in charge of Coelesyria. And he gathered together a great army, and he drew near to Jamnia. And he sent to Jonathan, the high priest,
verses.textLa: Et constituit Demetrius rex Apollonium ducem, qui præerat Cœlesyriæ: et congregavit exercitum magnum, et accessit ad Iamniam: et misit ad Ionathan summum sacerdotem,

verses.textEn: saying: “You alone resist us, and so I have been brought to derision and disgrace, because you exercise your power against us in the mountains.
verses.textLa: dicens: Tu solus resistis nobis: ego autem factus sum in derisum, et in opprobrium, propterea quia tu potestatem adversum nos exerces in montibus.

verses.textEn: Now, therefore, if you trust in your forces, descend to us in the plains, and there let us contest one another. For the power of war is with me.
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo si confidis in virtutibus tuis, descende ad nos in campum, et comparemus illic invicem: quia mecum est virtus bellorum.

verses.textEn: Inquire, and learn who I am, and the others, who are auxiliaries to me, who also say that your feet cannot stand before our face, for your fathers have twice been put to flight in their own land.
verses.textLa: Interroga, et disce quis sum ego, et ceteri, qui auxilio sunt mihi, qui et dicunt quia non potest stare pes vester ante faciem nostram, quia bis in fugam conversi sunt patres tui in terra sua:

verses.textEn: And now, how will you be able to withstand the horsemen, and so great an army in the plains, where there is no stone, or rock, or place to flee?”
verses.textLa: et nunc quomodo poteris sustinere equitatum et exercitum tantum in campo, ubi non est lapis, neque saxum, neque locus fugiendi?

verses.textEn: But when Jonathan heard the words of Apollonius, he was moved in his soul. And he chose ten thousand men, and he departed from Jerusalem, and Simon, his brother, met him to help him.
verses.textLa: Ut audivit autem Ionathas sermones Apollonii, motus est animo: et elegit decem millia virorum, et exiit ab Ierusalem, et occurrit ei Simon frater eius in adiutorium:

verses.textEn: And they positioned their tents near Joppa, but they excluded him from the city, because a garrison from Apollonius was in Joppa. And so, he attacked it.
verses.textLa: et applicuerunt castra in Ioppen, et exclusit eum a civitate: quia custodia Apollonii Ioppe erat, et oppugnavit eam.

verses.textEn: And those who were in the city, being terrified, opened to him. And so Jonathan obtained Joppa.
verses.textLa: Et exterriti qui erant in civitate, aperuerunt ei, et obtinuit Ionathas Ioppen.

verses.textEn: And Apollonius heard of it, and he moved three thousand horsemen, and a great army.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Apollonius, et admovit tria millia equitum, et exercitum multum.

verses.textEn: And he went toward Azotus, like one making a journey, but he suddenly departed into the plains, because he had a great number of horsemen, and he trusted in them. And Jonathan followed after him to Azotus, and they joined together in battle.
verses.textLa: Et abiit Azotum tamquam iter faciens, et statim exiit in campum, eo quod haberet multitudinem equitum, et confideret in eis. Et insecutus est eum Ionathas in Azotum, et commiserunt prælium.

verses.textEn: And Apollonius secretly left behind them in the camp a thousand horsemen.
verses.textLa: Et reliquit Apollonius in castris mille equites post eos occulte.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan realized that there was an ambush behind him, and they surrounded his camp, and they cast darts at the people from morning until evening.
verses.textLa: Et cognovit Ionathas quoniam insidiæ sunt post se, et circuierunt castra eius, et iecerunt iacula in populum a mane usque ad vesperam.
verses.notes: They used some of the many different types of catapults and other slinging machines of war, common during that time period, to cast darts and perhaps other things at the people. The army of Apollonius was casting the darts, and the people of Jonathan withstood them. The horses of Apollonius then became wearied, allowing Simon to then defeat them.

verses.textEn: But the people stood firm, just as Jonathan had instructed them, and their horses suffered hardships.
verses.textLa: Populus autem stabat, sicut præceperat Ionathas: et laboraverunt equi eorum.

verses.textEn: Then Simon drew forth his army, and he sent them against the legion. For the horsemen were wearied. And they were crushed by him, and they fled.
verses.textLa: Et eiecit Simon exercitum suum, et commisit contra legionem. Equites enim fatigati erant: et contriti sunt ab eo, et fugerunt.

verses.textEn: And those who were scattered throughout the plains fled to Azotus, and they entered into Bethdagon, so that, by their idol in that place, they might save themselves.
verses.textLa: Et qui dispersi sunt per campum, fugerunt in Azotum, et intraverunt in Bethdagon idolum suum, ut ibi se liberarent.

verses.textEn: But Jonathan set fire to Azotus and to the cities that were all around it, and he captured their spoils and the temple of Dagon. And he burned with fire all those who had fled into it.
verses.textLa: Et succendit Ionathas Azotum, et civitates, quæ erant in circuitu eius, et accepit spolia eorum, et templum Dagon: et omnes, qui fugerunt in illud, succendit igni.

verses.textEn: And so it was that those who fell by the sword, with those who were burned, were nearly eight thousand men.
verses.textLa: Et fuerunt qui ceciderunt gladio cum his, qui succensi sunt, fere octo millia virorum.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan, removed his encampment from there, and he took up a position against Askalon. And they went out of the city to meet him with great glory.
verses.textLa: Et movit inde Ionathas castra, et applicuit ea Ascalonem: et exierunt de civitate obviam illi in magna gloria.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan returned to Jerusalem with his own, having many spoils.
verses.textLa: Et reversus est Ionathas in Ierusalem cum suis, habentibus spolia multa.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when king Alexander heard these words, he added still more glory to Jonathan.
verses.textLa: Et factum est: ut audivit Alexander rex sermones istos, addidit adhuc glorificare Ionathan.

verses.textEn: And he sent him a clasp of gold, as is customary to be given to those who are of royal lineage. And he gave him Ekron, and all its borders, as a possession.
verses.textLa: Et misit ei fibulam auream, sicut consuetudo est dari cognatis regum. Et dedit ei Accaron, et omnes fines eius in possessionem.

verses.textEn: And the king of Egypt gathered together an army, like the sand that is along the shore of the sea, and many ships. And he sought to obtain the kingdom of Alexander by deceit, and to add it to his own kingdom.
verses.textLa: Et rex Ægypti congregavit exercitum, sicut arena, quæ est circa oram maris, et naves multas: et quærebat obtinere regnum Alexandri dolo, et addere illud regno suo.

verses.textEn: And he departed into Syria with words of peace, and they opened the cities to him, and they were meeting with him. For king Alexander had commanded them to go out to meet him, because he was his father-in-law.
verses.textLa: Et exiit in Syriam verbis pacificis, et aperiebant ei civitates, et occurrebant ei: quia mandaverat Alexander rex exire ei obviam, eo quod socer suus esset.

verses.textEn: But when Ptolemy entered a city, he placed garrisons of soldiers in each of the cities.
verses.textLa: Cum autem introiret civitatem Ptolemæus, ponebat custodias militum in singulis civitatibus.

verses.textEn: And when he drew near to Azotus, they revealed to him that the temple of Dagon had been burned with fire, and Azotus and its suburbs had been demolished, and bodies had been abandoned, and that, for those who had been cut to pieces in the war, they had made a tomb along the way.
verses.textLa: Et ut appropiavit Azoto, ostenderunt ei templum Dagon succensum igni, et Azotum, et cetera eius demolita, et corpora proiecta, et eorum, qui cæsi erant in bello, tumulos quos fecerant secus viam.

verses.textEn: And they told the king that Jonathan had done these things, so as to make him hated. But the king remained silent.
verses.textLa: Et narraverunt regi quia hæc fecit Ionathas, ut invidiam facerent ei: et tacuit rex.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan went to meet the king at Joppa with glory, and they greeted one another, and they stayed there.
verses.textLa: Et occurrit Ionathas regi in Ioppen cum gloria, et invicem se salutaverunt, et dormierunt illic.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan went with the king as far as the river, which is called Eleutherus. And he returned to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et abiit Ionathas cum rege usque ad fluvium, qui vocatur Eleutherus: et reversus est in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: But king Ptolemy obtained the dominion of the coastal cities, as far as Seleucia, and he devised evil plans against Alexander.
verses.textLa: Rex autem Ptolemæus obtinuit dominium civitatum usque Seleuciam maritimam, et cogitabat in Alexandrum consilia mala.

verses.textEn: And he sent ambassadors to Demetrius, saying: “Come, let us compose a pact between us, and I will give you my daughter, whom Alexander had, and you will reign in the kingdom of your father.
verses.textLa: Et misit legatos ad Demetrium, dicens: VENI, componamus inter nos pactum, et dabo tibi filiam meam, quam habet Alexander, et regnabis in regno patris tui.

verses.textEn: For I regret that I have given him my daughter. For he has sought to kill me.”
verses.textLa: Pœnitet enim me quod dederim illi filiam meam: quæsivit enim me occidere.

verses.textEn: And he slandered him, because he coveted his kingdom.
verses.textLa: Et vituperavit eum, propterea quod concupierat regnum eius.

verses.textEn: And he took away his daughter, and he gave her to Demetrius, and he alienated himself from Alexander, and his hostilities were made manifest.
verses.textLa: Et abstulit filiam suam, et dedit eam Demetrio, et alienavit se ab Alexandro, et manifestæ sunt inimicitiæ eius.

verses.textEn: And Ptolemy entered Antioch, and he placed two diadems upon his head, that of Egypt, and that of Asia.
verses.textLa: Et intravit Ptolemæus Antiochiam, et imposuit duo diademata capiti suo, Ægypti, et Asiæ.

verses.textEn: Now king Alexander was in Cilicia at that time, because the people of those places were rebelling.
verses.textLa: Alexander autem rex erat in Cilicia illis temporibus: quia rebellabant qui erant in locis illis.

verses.textEn: And when Alexander heard of it, he came against him in warfare. And king Ptolemy led forth his army, and he met him with a strong hand, and he put him to flight.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Alexander, et venit ad eum in bellum: et produxit Ptolemæus rex exercitum, et occurrit ei in manu valida, et fugavit eum.

verses.textEn: And Alexander fled into Arabia, so as to be protected there. And king Ptolemy was exalted.
verses.textLa: Et fugit Alexander in Arabiam, ut ibi protegeretur: rex autem Ptolemæus exaltatus est.

verses.textEn: And Zabdiel the Arab took off the head of Alexander, and he sent it to Ptolemy.
verses.textLa: Et abstulit Zabdiel Arabs caput Alexandri; et misit Ptolemæo.

verses.textEn: And king Ptolemy died on the third day, and those who were in the strongholds were destroyed by those who were in the camp.
verses.textLa: Et rex Ptolemæus mortuus est in die tertia: et qui erant in munitionibus, perierunt ab his, qui erant intra castra.

verses.textEn: And Demetrius reigned in the one hundred and sixty-seventh year.
verses.textLa: Et regnavit Demetrius anno centesimo sexagesimo septimo.

verses.textEn: In those days, Jonathan gathered together those who were in Judea, in order to fight against the stronghold that was in Jerusalem. And they made many machines of war against it.
verses.textLa: In diebus illis congregavit Ionathas eos, qui erant in Iudæa, ut expugnarent arcem, quæ est in Ierusalem: et fecerunt contra eam machinas multas.

verses.textEn: And so, certain men of iniquity, who hated their own people, went forth to king Demetrius, and they reported to him that Jonathan was besieging the stronghold.
verses.textLa: Et abierunt quidam qui oderant gentem suam viri iniqui ad regem Demetrium, et renunciaverunt ei quod Ionathas obsideret arcem.

verses.textEn: And when he heard it, he became angry. And immediately he came to Ptolemais, and he wrote to Jonathan that he should not besiege the stronghold, but that he should meet with him promptly, for a discussion.
verses.textLa: Et ut audivit, iratus est: et statim venit ad Ptolemaidam, et scripsit Ionathæ ne obsideret arcem, sed occurreret sibi ad colloquium festinato.

verses.textEn: But when Jonathan heard this, he ordered them to besiege it. And he chose some from the elders of Israel and from the priests, and he put himself in danger.
verses.textLa: Ut audivit autem Ionathas, iussit obsidere: et elegit de senioribus Israel, et de sacerdotibus, et dedit se periculo.

verses.textEn: And he took gold, and silver, and vestments, and many other presents, and he went to the king at Ptolemais, and he found favor in his sight.
verses.textLa: Et accepit aurum, et argentum, et vestem, et alia xenia multa, et abiit ad regem Ptolemaidam, et invenit gratiam in conspectu eius.
verses.notes: The word ‘xenia’ is an unusual word referring to gifts given to guests.

verses.textEn: And some of the iniquitous from his nation came forward with objections against him.
verses.textLa: Et interpellabant adversus eum quidam iniqui ex gente sua.
verses.notes: It was a custom in ancient times, if one went to a king to find favor, for those who were against him to also send a delegation, to oppose him. Jesus refers to this in one of his parables about himself.

verses.textEn: And the king treated him just as those who were before him had treated him. And he exalted him in the sight of all his friends.
verses.textLa: Et fecit ei rex sicut fecerant ei, qui ante eum fuerant: et exaltavit eum in conspectu omnium amicorum suorum,

verses.textEn: And he confirmed him in the high priesthood and in all the other honors that he held before, and he made him the leader of his friends.
verses.textLa: et statuit ei principatum sacerdotii, et quæcumque alia habuit prius pretiosa, et fecit eum principem amicorum.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan requested of the king that he would make Judea free from tribute, along with the three districts, and Samaria, and its confines. And he promised him three hundred talents.
verses.textLa: Et postulavit Ionathas a rege ut immunem faceret Iudæam, et tres toparchias, et Samariam, et confines eius: et promisit ei talenta trecenta.

verses.textEn: And the king consented. And he wrote letters to Jonathan about all these things, continuing in this way:
verses.textLa: Et consensit rex: et scripsit Ionathæ epistolas de his omnibus, hunc modum continentes:

verses.textEn: “King Demetrius to his brother Jonathan, and to the nation of the Jews: greetings.
verses.textLa: REX Demetrius fratri Ionathæ salutem, et genti Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: We are sending you a copy of the letter that we wrote to Lasthenes, our parent, about you, so that you will know.
verses.textLa: Exemplum epistolæ, quam scripsimus Lastheni parenti nostro de vobis, misimus ad vos ut sciretis:

verses.textEn: ‘King Demetrius to Lasthenes, his parent: greetings.
verses.textLa: Rex Demetrius Lastheni parenti salutem.

verses.textEn: We have determined to do good to the people of the Jews, who are our friends and who keep to what is just with us, because of their good will, which they hold toward us.
verses.textLa: Genti Iudæorum amicis nostris, et conservantibus quæ iusta sunt apud nos, decrevimus benefacere propter benignitatem ipsorum, quam erga nos habent.

verses.textEn: Therefore, we have assigned to them all the parts of Judea, and the three cities, Lydda and Ramatha, which were added to Judea from Samaria, and all their confines, to be set apart for all those sacrificing in Jerusalem, in place of that which the king previously received from them each year, and in place of the fruits of the land and of the fruit trees.
verses.textLa: Statuimus ergo illis omnes fines Iudææ, et tres civitates, Lydan, et Ramathan, quæ additæ sunt Iudææ ex Samaria, et omnes confines earum sequestrari omnibus sacrificantibus in Ierosolymis pro his, quæ ab eis prius accipiebat rex per singulos annos, et pro fructibus terræ, et pomorum.
verses.notes:
The word ‘fines’ does not always refer to limits or borders (the last parts), it can also refer simply to any part or, as in this case, to all parts of a particular region.
 Many translations add ‘Aphairema’ after ‘the three cities,’ but the Latin text just does not have that place name.
 In other words, the tributes (similar to taxes) that would have gone to the king, as in previous years, will now go to Jerusalem to pay for various expenses related to the sacrifices there.

verses.textEn: And, as for the rest of that which pertains to us from tithes and tributes, from this time forward, we release them from these, as well as from the drying areas of salt and the crowns that were presented to us.
verses.textLa: Et alia, quæ ad nos pertinebant decimarum, et tributorum ex hoc tempore remittimus eis: et areas salinarum, et coronas, quæ nobis deferebantur,

verses.textEn: All these, we concede to them, and nothing of these shall be revoked, from this time forward and for all time.
verses.textLa: omnia ipsis concedimus: et nihil horum irritum erit ex hoc, et in omne tempus.

verses.textEn: Now, therefore, take care to make a copy of these things, and let it be given to Jonathan and set upon the holy mountain, in an honorable place.’ ”
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo curate facere horum exemplum, et detur Ionathæ, et ponatur in monte sancto, in loco celebri.

verses.textEn: And king Demetrius, seeing that the land was quieted in his sight and that nothing resisted him, sent all his forces away, each one to his own place, except the foreign army, which he had drawn together from the islands of the nations. And so all the troops of his fathers were hostile to him.
verses.textLa: Et videns Demetrius rex quod siluit terra in conspectu suo, et nihil ei resistit, dimisit totum exercitum suum, unumquemque in locum suum, excepto peregrino exercitu, quem contraxit ab insulis Gentium: et inimici erant ei omnes exercitus patrum eius.

verses.textEn: But there was a certain one, Trypho, who was previously on Alexander’s side. And he saw that all the army murmured against Demetrius, and so he went to Imalkue the Arab, who raised Antiochus, the son of Alexander.
verses.textLa: Tryphon autem erat quidam partium Alexandri prius: et vidit quoniam omnis exercitus murmurabat contra Demetrium, et ivit ad Emalchuel Arabem, qui nutriebat Antiochum filium Alexandri:

verses.textEn: And he persuaded him to deliver him to him, so that he would reign in his father’s place. And he reported to him what Demetrius had done, and that his army was hostile to him. And he remained there for many days.
verses.textLa: et assidebat ei, ut traderet eum ipsi, ut regnaret loco patris sui: et enunciavit ei quanta fecit Demetrius, et inimicitias exercituum eius adversus illum. Et mansit ibi diebus multis.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan sent to king Demetrius, so that he would cast out those who were in the stronghold in Jerusalem and those who were with the garrisons, because they fought against Israel.
verses.textLa: Et misit Ionathas ad Demetrium regem, ut eiiceret eos, qui in arce erant in Ierusalem, et qui in præsidiis erant: quia impugnabant Israel.

verses.textEn: And Demetrius sent to Jonathan, saying: “I will not only do this for you and your people, but I will elevate your glory and your nation, when opportunity shall serve.
verses.textLa: Et misit Demetrius ad Ionathan, dicens: Non hæc tantum faciam tibi, et genti tuæ, sed gloria illustrabo te, et gentem tuam cum fuerit opportunum.

verses.textEn: Now, therefore, you will do well if you send men as auxiliaries to me. For all my army has withdrawn from me.”
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo recte feceris, si miseris in auxilium mihi viros: quia discessit omnis exercitus meus.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan sent three thousand strong men to him at Antioch. And they came to the king, and the king was delighted at their arrival.
verses.textLa: Et misit ei Ionathas tria millia virorum fortium Antiochiam: et venerunt ad regem, et delectatus est rex in adventu eorum.

verses.textEn: And those who were of the city gathered together, one hundred and twenty thousand men, and they wanted to execute the king.
verses.textLa: Et convenerunt qui erant de civitate, centum viginti millia virorum, et volebant interficere regem.

verses.textEn: And the king fled into the royal court. And those who were of the city, occupied the passageways of the city, and they began to fight.
verses.textLa: Et fugit rex in aulam: et occupaverunt qui erant de civitate, itinera civitatis, et cœperunt pugnare.

verses.textEn: And the king called the Jews to his assistance. And they came together before him at the same time, and then they all dispersed themselves throughout the city.
verses.textLa: Et vocavit rex Iudæos in auxilium, et convenerunt omnes simul ad eum, et dispersi sunt omnes per civitatem:

verses.textEn: And they killed, in that day, one hundred thousand men, and they set fire to the city, and they seized many spoils in that day, and they freed the king.
verses.textLa: et occiderunt in illa die centum millia hominum, et succenderunt civitatem, et ceperunt spolia multa in die illa, et liberaverunt regem.

verses.textEn: And those who were of the city saw that the Jews had taken the city, just as they wanted, and they were weakened in their resolve, and they cried out to the king with supplication, saying,
verses.textLa: Et viderunt qui erant de civitate, quod obtinuissent Iudæi civitatem sicut volebant: et infirmati sunt mente sua, et clamaverunt ad regem cum precibus, dicentes:

verses.textEn: “Grant us a pledge, and let the Jews cease from assailing us and the city.”
verses.textLa: Da nobis dextras, et cessent Iudæi oppugnare nos, et civitatem.
verses.notes: The word ‘dextras’ can refer to the right side or the right hand, but in this context it refers to a pledge or promise or treaty, sworn to with the right hand.

verses.textEn: And they threw down their arms, and they made peace. And the Jews were glorified in the sight of the king and in the sight of all who were in his realm. And they became renowned in the kingdom, and they returned to Jerusalem, holding many spoils.
verses.textLa: Et proiecerunt arma sua, et fecerunt pacem, et glorificati sunt Iudæi in conspectu regis, et in conspectu omnium, qui erant in regno eius, et nominati sunt in regno: et regressi sunt in Ierusalem habentes spolia multa.

verses.textEn: And so king Demetrius sat on the throne of his kingdom. And the land was quieted in his sight.
verses.textLa: Et sedit Demetrius rex in sede regni sui: et siluit terra in conspectu eius.

verses.textEn: And he falsified everything whatsoever that he had said. And he alienated himself from Jonathan, and he did not repay him according to the benefits that he had received in tribute from him. And he vexed him greatly.
verses.textLa: Et mentitus est omnia quæcumque dixit, et abalienavit se a Ionatha, et non retribuit ei secundum beneficia, quæ sibi tribuerat, et vexabat eum valde.

verses.textEn: But after this, Trypho returned, and with him was Antiochus, the adolescent boy, and he reigned, and he put a diadem on himself.
verses.textLa: Post hæc autem reversus est Tryphon, et Antiochus cum eo puer adolescens, et regnavit, et imposuit sibi diadema.

verses.textEn: And there assembled before him all the troops, which Demetrius had dispersed, and they fought against him. And he turned his back and fled.
verses.textLa: Et congregati sunt ad eum omnes exercitus, quos disperserat Demetrius, et pugnaverunt contra eum: et fugit, et terga vertit.

verses.textEn: And Trypho took the elephants, and he obtained Antioch.
verses.textLa: Et accepit Tryphon bestias, et obtinuit Antiochiam:

verses.textEn: And young Antiochus wrote to Jonathan, saying: “I confirm you in the priesthood, and I appoint you over the four cities, so as to be among the king’s friends.”
verses.textLa: Et scripsit Antiochus adolescens Ionathæ, dicens: Constituo tibi sacerdotium, et constituo te super quattuor civitates, ut sis de amicis regis.

verses.textEn: And he sent him vessels of gold for his ministry, and he gave him the authority to drink from gold, and to be clothed in purple, and to have a golden clasp.
verses.textLa: Et misit illi vasa aurea in ministerium, et dedit ei potestatem bibendi in auro, et esse in purpura, et habere fibulam auream:

verses.textEn: And he appointed his brother Simon as governor, from the borders of Tyre, all the way to the borders of Egypt.
verses.textLa: et Simonem fratrem eius constituit ducem a terminis Tyri usque ad fines Ægypti.

verses.textEn: Then Jonathan went out, and he passed through the cities across the river. And all the armies of Syria were gathered together in assistance to him, and he came to Askalon, and those from the city met him honorably.
verses.textLa: Et exiit Ionathas, et perambulabat trans flumen civitates: et congregatus est ad eum omnis exercitus Syriæ in auxilium, et venit Ascalonem, et occurrerunt ei honorifice de civitate.

verses.textEn: And he went from there to Gaza. And those who were in Gaza closed themselves in. And so he besieged it, and he burned all that was around the city, and he plundered it.
verses.textLa: Et abiit inde Gazam: et concluserunt se qui erant Gazæ: et obsedit eam, et succendit quæ erant in circuitu civitatis, et prædatus est ea.

verses.textEn: And those of Gaza petitioned Jonathan, and he pledged to them with his right hand, and he accepted their sons as hostages and sent them to Jerusalem. And he traveled through the country, as far as Damascus.
verses.textLa: Et rogaverunt Gazenses Ionathan, et dedit illis dexteram: et accepit filios eorum obsides, et misit illos in Ierusalem: et perambulavit regionem usque Damascum.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan heard that the leaders of Demetrius were acting treacherously at Kadesh, which is in Galilee, with a great army, intending to remove him from the affairs of the kingdom.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Ionathas quod prævaricati sunt principes Demetrii in Cades, quæ est in Galilæa, cum exercitu multo, volentes eum removere a negotio regni:

verses.textEn: And he went to meet them. But he left his brother Simon behind in the countryside.
verses.textLa: et occurrit illis: fratrem autem suum Simonem reliquit intra provinciam.

verses.textEn: And Simon took a position against Bethzur, and he assailed it for many days, and he closed them in.
verses.textLa: Et applicuit Simon ad Bethsuram, et expugnabat eam diebus multis, et conclusit eos.

verses.textEn: And they asked him to accept a pledge, and he granted this to them. And he cast them out of there, and he seized the city, and he placed a garrison in it.
verses.textLa: Et postulaverunt ab eo dextras accipere, et dedit illis: et eiecit eos inde, et cepit civitatem, et posuit in ea præsidium.
verses.notes: Again, the right hand was raised as a pledge (as is still the custom today).

verses.textEn: And Jonathan and his camp took a position by the water of Gennesaret, and, before first light, they were standing watch in the plains of Hazor.
verses.textLa: Et Ionathas, et castra eius applicuerunt ad aquam Genesar, et ante lucem vigilaverunt in campo Asor.

verses.textEn: And behold, an army of foreigners met him in the plains. And they set up an ambush against him in the mountains. But he met them from the opposite direction.
verses.textLa: Et ecce castra alienigenarum occurrebant in campo, et tendebant ei insidias in montibus: ipse autem occurrit ex adverso.
verses.notes: In this case, ‘ex adverso’ does not mean ‘against,’ but rather ‘from the opposite direction.’ So the enemy laid an ambush against Jonathan, but he came at them from the other direction, giving him an advantage.

verses.textEn: Yet those lying in ambush then rose up from their places and joined them in combat.
verses.textLa: Insidiæ vero exsurrexerunt de locis suis, et commiserunt prælium.

verses.textEn: And all those who were from Jonathan’s side fled, and not one of them was left, except Mattathias, the son of Absalom, and Judas, the son of Chalphi, the leader of military training.
verses.textLa: Et fugerunt qui erant ex parte Ionathæ omnes, et nemo relictus est ex eis, nisi Mathathias filius Absolomi, et Iudas filius Calphi, princeps militiæ exercitus.
verses.notes: Despite the advantage of having foiled the ambush, the men on Jonathan’s side fled during combat. The phrase “princeps militiæ exercitus” has the singular ‘princeps,’ so it refers only to Judas, not also to Mattathias. The last two words each could be taken to refer to the army, but in that case the phrase would be redundant. The last word, ‘exercitus,’ could also be a participle. In other words, Judas was the leader of military training, not the leader of the whole army. This makes more sense because, if Judas and Mattathias were the two leaders of the army, then everyone would not have fled. But if Mattathias were merely a soldier, and Judas was in charge of training soldiers, the others could have fled despite their example.

verses.textEn: And so Jonathan tore his garments, and he placed dirt on his head, and he prayed.
verses.textLa: Et scidit Ionathas vestimenta sua, et posuit terram in capite suo, et oravit.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan turned back toward them in battle, and he put them to flight, and they fought.
verses.textLa: Et reversus est Ionathas ad eos in prælium, et convertit eos in fugam, et pugnaverunt.

verses.textEn: And when those from his side, who had fled, saw this, they returned to him, and with him they all pursued them, even to Kadesh, to their camp, and they even passed beyond there.
verses.textLa: Et viderunt qui fugiebant partis illius, et reversi sunt ad eum, et insequebantur cum eo omnes usque Cades ad castra sua, et pervenerunt usque illuc.

verses.textEn: And there fell from the foreigners on that day three thousand men. And Jonathan returned to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et ceciderunt de alienigenis in die illa tria millia virorum: et reversus est Ionathas in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan saw that time was on his side, and he chose men, and he sent them to Rome, to confirm and renew the peace agreement with them.
verses.textLa: Et vidit Ionathas quia tempus eum iuvat, et elegit viros, et misit eos Romam statuere, et renovare cum eis amicitiam:

verses.textEn: And he sent letters to the Spartans, and to other places, according to the same form.
verses.textLa: et ad Spartiatas, et ad alia loca misit epistolas secundum eamdem formam:

verses.textEn: And they went to Rome and entered into the senate house, and they said, “Jonathan, the high priest, and the nation of the Jews, have sent us to renew the peace and alliance, as it was before.”
verses.textLa: et abierunt Romam, et intraverunt curiam, et dixerunt: Ionathas summus sacerdos, et gens Iudæorum miserunt nos, ut renovaremus amicitiam, et societatem secundum pristinum.

verses.textEn: And they gave letters to them, to those in each place, so that they would lead them into the land of Judah with peace.
verses.textLa: Et dederunt illis epistolas ad ipsos per loca, ut deducerent eos in terram Iuda cum pace.

verses.textEn: And this is a copy of the letters that Jonathan wrote to the Spartans:
verses.textLa: Et hoc est exemplum epistolarum, quas scripsit Ionathas Spartiatis:

verses.textEn: “Jonathan, the high priest, and the elders of the people, and the priests, and the rest of the people of the Jews, to the Spartans, their brothers: greetings.
verses.textLa: IONATHAS summus sacerdos, et seniores gentis, et sacerdotes, et reliquus populus Iudæorum Spartiatis fratribus salutem.

verses.textEn: Now, some time ago, letters were sent to Onias, the high priest from Arius, who reigned then among you, so that you would be our brothers, just as the copy that is written below states.
verses.textLa: Iampridem missæ erant epistolæ ad Oniam summum sacerdotem ab Ario, qui regnabat apud vos, quoniam estis fratres nostri, sicut rescriptum continet, quod subiectum est.

verses.textEn: And Onias received the man whom you had sent with honor. And he received the letters, in which was conveyed the alliance and peace treaty.
verses.textLa: Et suscepit Onias virum, qui missus fuerat, cum honore: et accepit epistolas, in quibus significabatur de societate, et amicitia.

verses.textEn: We, though, have no need of these things, having for our solace the sacred books, which are in our hands.
verses.textLa: Nos, cum nullo horum indigeremus, habentes solatio sanctos libros, qui sunt in manibus nostris,

verses.textEn: We prefer to send to you, so as to renew the brotherhood and friendship, lest we should, in effect, become a stranger to you, for much time has passed since you sent to us.
verses.textLa: maluimus mittere ad vos renovare fraternitatem, et amicitiam, ne forte alieni efficiamur a vobis: multa enim tempora transierunt, ex quo misistis ad nos.

verses.textEn: Therefore, we will remember you, at all times without ceasing, in our solemnities and other days, when it is fitting, in the sacrifices that we offer, and in our observances, just as it is fitting and right to remember brothers.
verses.textLa: Nos ergo in omni tempore sine intermissione in diebus sollemnibus, et ceteris, quibus oportet, memores sumus vestri in sacrificiis, quæ offerimus, et in observationibus, sicut fas est, et decet meminisse fratrum.

verses.textEn: And so, we rejoice at your glory.
verses.textLa: Lætamur itaque de gloria vestra.

verses.textEn: But many tribulations and many wars have surrounded us, and the kings who are around us have fought against us.
verses.textLa: Nos autem circumdederunt multæ tribulationes, et multa prælia, et impugnaverunt nos reges qui sunt in circuitu nostro.

verses.textEn: But we are not willing to trouble you, nor the rest of our allies and friends, about these battles.
verses.textLa: Noluimus ergo vobis molesti esse, neque ceteris sociis et amicis nostris in his præliis.

verses.textEn: For we have assistance from heaven, and we have been delivered, and our enemies have been humbled.
verses.textLa: Habuimus enim de cælo auxilium, et liberati sumus nos, et humiliati sunt inimici nostri.

verses.textEn: And so, we have chosen Numenius, the son of Antiochus, and Antipater, the son of Jason, and we have sent them to the Romans, to renew the former peace treaty and alliance with them.
verses.textLa: Elegimus itaque Numenium Antiochi filium, et Antipatrem Iasonis filium, et misimus ad Romanos renovare cum eis amicitiam, et societatem pristinam.

verses.textEn: And so, we have commanded them to also come to you, and to greet you, and to deliver our letters to you, about the renewal of our brotherhood.
verses.textLa: Mandavimus itaque eis ut veniant etiam ad vos, et salutent vos: et reddant vobis epistolas nostras de innovatione fraternitatis nostræ.

verses.textEn: And now, you would do well to respond to us about these things.”
verses.textLa: Et nunc benefacietis respondentes nobis ad hæc.

verses.textEn: And this is a copy of the letters that he sent to Onias:
verses.textLa: Et hoc est rescriptum epistolarum, quod miserat Oniæ:

verses.textEn: “Arius, king of the Spartans, to Onias, the great priest: greetings.
verses.textLa: Arius, rex Spartiatarum Oniæ sacerdoti magno salutem.

verses.textEn: It is found in scripture, about the Spartans and the Jews, that they are brothers, and that they are of the family of Abraham.
verses.textLa: Inventum est in scriptura de Spartiatis, et Iudæis, quoniam sunt fratres, et quod sunt de genere Abraham.

verses.textEn: And since we know these things, you would do well to write to us about your peace.
verses.textLa: Et nunc ex quo hæc cognovimus, benefacitis scribentes nobis de pace vestra:

verses.textEn: But we also have written back to you that our cattle and our possessions are yours, and yours are ours. And so, we have commanded that these things should be announced to you.”
verses.textLa: Sed et nos rescripsimus vobis: Pecora nostra et possessiones nostræ, vestræ sunt: et vestræ, nostræ: mandavimus itaque hæc nunciari vobis.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan heard that the leaders from Demetrius had returned again with a greater army than before, so as to fight against him.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Ionathas quoniam regressi sunt principes Demetrii cum exercitu multo supra quam prius, pugnare adversus eum.

verses.textEn: And so, he departed from Jerusalem, and he met them in the region of Hamath. For he did not give them time to enter into his own region.
verses.textLa: Et exiit ab Ierusalem, et occurrit eis in Amathite regione: non enim dederat eis spatium ut ingrederentur regionem eius.

verses.textEn: And he sent spies into their camp, and, returning, they reported that they planned to come upon them in the night.
verses.textLa: Et misit speculatores in castra eorum: et reversi renunciaverunt quod constituunt supervenire illis nocte.

verses.textEn: And when the sun had set, Jonathan instructed his men to stand watch, and to be in arms, ready to fight, all night long, and he stationed guards around the camp.
verses.textLa: Cum occidisset autem sol, præcepit Ionathas suis vigilare, et esse in armis paratos ad pugnam tota nocte, et posuit custodes per circuitum castrorum.

verses.textEn: And the adversaries heard that Jonathan was prepared, with his own, for warfare. And they were struck with fear and dread in their heart. And they kindled fires in their camp.
verses.textLa: Et audierunt adversarii quod paratus est Ionathas cum suis in bello: et timuerunt, et formidaverunt in corde suo: et accenderunt focos in castris suis.
verses.notes: The enemy kindled fires in their camp and then they fled. The fires would trick Jonathan and his men into thinking that they were still in the camp.

verses.textEn: But Jonathan, and those who were with him, did not know about it until morning. For they saw the lights burning.
verses.textLa: Ionathas autem, et qui cum eo erant, non cognoverunt usque mane: videbant autem luminaria ardentia,

verses.textEn: And Jonathan pursued them, but did not overtake them. For they had crossed the river Eleutherus.
verses.textLa: et secutus est eos Ionathas, et non comprehendit eos: transierant enim flumen Eleutherum.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan diverted toward the Arabians, who are called Zabadeans. And he struck them and took their spoils.
verses.textLa: Et divertit Ionathas ad Arabas, qui vocantur Zabadæi, et percussit eos, et accepit spolia eorum.

verses.textEn: And he regrouped and came to Damascus, and he passed through all that region.
verses.textLa: Et iunxit, et venit Damascum, et perambulabat omnem regionem illam.
verses.notes: The verb ‘iunxit’ can refer to uniting or joining, which in this context would mean that Jonathan regrouped before moving on, or it can refer to going on to an adjoining place.

verses.textEn: But Simon went forth and came as far as Askalon, and the nearby fortresses, but he turned aside to Joppa and occupied it,
verses.textLa: Simon autem exiit, et venit usque ad Ascalonem, et ad proxima præsidia: et declinavit in Ioppen, et occupavit eam

verses.textEn: (for he had heard that they intended to hand over the fortress that was on the side of Demetrius) and he stationed a guard there to keep it.
verses.textLa: (audivit enim quod vellent præsidium tradere partibus Demetrii) et posuit ibi custodes ut custodirent eam.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan returned, and he called together the elders of the people, and he decided with them to build fortresses in Judea,
verses.textLa: Et reversus est Ionathas, et convocavit seniores populi, et cogitavit cum eis ædificare præsidia in Iudæa,

verses.textEn: and to build up the walls in Jerusalem, and to raise a great height between the stronghold and the city, in order to separate it from the city, so that it would stand alone and would have neither buying, nor selling there.
verses.textLa: et ædificare muros in Ierusalem, et exaltare altitudinem magnam inter medium arcis et civitatis, ut separaret eam a civitate, ut esset ipsa singulariter, et neque emant, neque vendant.

verses.textEn: And they came together to build up the city. And the wall that was over the brook, toward the rising of the sun, was fallen. And he repaired that which is called Chaphenatha.
verses.textLa: Et convenerunt, ut ædificarent civitatem: et cecidit murus, qui erat super torrentem ab ortu solis, et reparavit eum, qui vocatur Caphetetha:

verses.textEn: And Simon rebuilt Adida in Shephelah, and he fortified it, and he set up gates and bars.
verses.textLa: et Simon ædificavit Adiada in Sephela, et munivit eam, et imposuit portas, et seras.

verses.textEn: And so, when Trypho had decided to reign over Asia, and to assume the diadem, and to extend his hand against king Antiochus,
verses.textLa: Et cum cogitasset Tryphon regnare Asiæ, et assumere diadema, et extendere manum in Antiochum regem:

verses.textEn: he was afraid, lest Jonathan might not permit him, but might fight against him. So he sought to seize him and to kill him. And he rose up and went to Bethshan.
verses.textLa: timens ne forte non permitteret eum Ionathas, sed pugnaret adversus eum, quærebat comprehendere eum, et occidere. Et exurgens abiit in Bethsan.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan went out to meet him with forty thousand men chosen for battle, and he came to Bethshan.
verses.textLa: Et exivit Ionathas obviam illi cum quadraginta millibus virorum electorum in prælium, et venit Bethsan.

verses.textEn: And when Trypho saw that Jonathan came with a great army to extend his hand against him, he was afraid.
verses.textLa: Et vidit Tryphon quia venit Ionathas cum exercitu multo ut extenderet in eum manus, timuit.

verses.textEn: And so he received him with honor, and he commended him to all his friends, and he gave him gifts. And he instructed his troops to obey him, just as himself.
verses.textLa: Et excepit eum cum honore, et commendavit eum omnibus amicis suis, et dedit ei munera: et præcepit exercitibus suis ut obedirent ei, sicut sibi.

verses.textEn: And he said to Jonathan: “Why have you troubled all the people, when there is no war between us?
verses.textLa: Et dixit Ionathæ: Ut quid vexasti universum populum, cum bellum nobis non sit?

verses.textEn: And now, send them back to their houses, but choose for yourself a few men, who may remain with you, and come with me to Ptolemais, and I will deliver it to you, and the rest of the fortresses, and the army, and all who are in charge of governing, and I will turn and go away. For this is the reason that I came.”
verses.textLa: Et nunc remitte eos in domos suas: elige autem tibi viros paucos, qui tecum sint, et veni mecum Ptolemaidam, et tradam eam tibi, et reliqua præsidia, et exercitum, et universos præpositos negotii, et conversus abibo: propterea enim veni.

verses.textEn: And Jonathan believed him, and he did as he said. And he sent away his army, and they departed into the land of Judah.
verses.textLa: Et credidit ei, et fecit sicut dixit: et dimisit exercitum, et abierunt in terram Iuda.

verses.textEn: But he retained with him three thousand men, of whom he sent two thousand into Galilee, and one thousand came with him.
verses.textLa: Retinuit autem secum tria millia virorum: ex quibus remisit in Galilæam duo millia, mille autem venerunt cum eo.

verses.textEn: But when Jonathan entered into Ptolemais, those of Ptolemais closed the gates of the city, and they captured him. And all those who entered with him, they executed with the sword.
verses.textLa: Ut autem intravit Ptolemaidam Ionathas, clauserunt portas civitatis Ptolemenses: et comprehenderunt eum: et omnes, qui cum eo intraverant, gladio interfecerunt.

verses.textEn: And Trypho sent an army and horsemen into Galilee, and into the great plain, to destroy all the associates of Jonathan.
verses.textLa: Et misit Tryphon exercitum, et equites in Galilæam, et in campum magnum ut perderent omnes socios Ionathæ.

verses.textEn: But, when they had thought that Jonathan had been captured and slain, along with all who were with him, they encouraged one another, and they went out prepared for battle.
verses.textLa: At illi cum cognovissent quia comprehensus est Ionathas, et periit, et omnes, qui cum eo erant, hortati sunt semetipsos, et exierunt parati in prælium.

verses.textEn: Then those who had pursued them, seeing that they stood for their lives, were turned back.
verses.textLa: Et videntes hi, qui insecuti fuerant, quia pro anima res est illis, reversi sunt:

verses.textEn: And so, they all came into the land of Judah with peace. And they bewailed Jonathan, and those who had been with him, exceedingly. And Israel mourned with great lamentation.
verses.textLa: illi autem venerunt omnes cum pace in terram Iuda. Et planxerunt Ionathan, et eos, qui cum ipso fuerant, valde: et luxit Israel luctu magno.

verses.textEn: Then all the nations that were all around them sought to crush them. For they said:
verses.textLa: Et quæsierunt omnes gentes, quæ erant in circuitu eorum, conterere eos. Dixerunt enim:

verses.textEn: “They have no leader or helper. Now therefore, let us fight against them and take away the memory of them from among men.”
verses.textLa: Non habent principem, et adiuvantem: nunc ergo expugnemus illos, et tollamus de hominibus memoriam eorum.

verses.textEn: And Simon heard that Trypho had gathered together an immense army to come to the land of Judah and to lay waste to it.
verses.textLa: Et audivit Simon quod congregavit Tryphon exercitum copiosum ut veniret in terram Iuda, et attereret eam.

verses.textEn: Seeing that the people were fearful and trembling, he went up to Jerusalem, and he gathered together the people.
verses.textLa: Videns quia in tremore populus est, et in timore, ascendit Ierusalem, et congregavit populum:

verses.textEn: And exhorting them, he said: “You know what great battles I, and my brothers, and the house of my father, have fought for the laws and for the holy places, and the anguish that we have seen.
verses.textLa: et adhortans dixit: Vos scitis quanta ego, et fratres mei, et domus patris mei fecimus pro legibus, et pro sanctis prælia, et angustias quales vidimus:

verses.textEn: As a result of these things, all my brothers have perished for the sake of Israel, and I have been left alone.
verses.textLa: horum gratia perierunt fratres mei omnes propter Israel, et relictus sum ego solus.

verses.textEn: And now, it is not necessary for me to spare my life in any time of tribulation. For I am not better than my brothers.
verses.textLa: Et nunc non mihi contingat parcere animæ meæ in omni tempore tribulationis: non enim melior sum fratribus meis.

verses.textEn: And so, I will vindicate my people and the sanctuary, and likewise our children and wives. For all the Gentiles have gathered together to crush us, solely out of malice.”
verses.textLa: Vindicabo itaque gentem meam, et sancta, natos quoque nostros, et uxores: quia congregatæ sunt universæ Gentes conterere nos inimicitiæ gratia.

verses.textEn: And the spirit of the people was immediately enkindled, when they heard these words.
verses.textLa: Et accensus est spiritus populi simul ut audivit sermones istos:

verses.textEn: And they responded with a loud voice, saying: “You are our leader in place of Judas and of Jonathan, your brother.
verses.textLa: et responderunt voce magna dicentes: Tu es dux noster loco Iudæ, et Ionathæ fratris tui:

verses.textEn: Fight our battles, and we will do whatever you tell us to do.”
verses.textLa: pugna prælium nostrum: et omnia, quæcumque dixeris nobis, faciemus.

verses.textEn: And so, gathering together all the men of war, he accelerated the completion of all the walls of Jerusalem, and he fortified it all around.
verses.textLa: Et congregans omnes viros bellatores, acceleravit consummare universos muros Ierusalem, et munivit eam in gyro.

verses.textEn: And he sent Jonathan, the son of Absalom, and with him a new army, into Joppa, and he cast out those who were in it, and he himself remained there.
verses.textLa: Et misit Ionathan filium Absalomi et cum eo exercitum novum in Ioppen, et eiectis his, qui erant in ea, remansit illic ipse.

verses.textEn: And Trypho moved from Ptolemais, with a great army, to come into the land of Judah, and Jonathan was with him in custody.
verses.textLa: Et movit Tryphon a Ptolemaida cum exercitu multo, ut veniret in terram Iuda, et Ionathas cum eo in custodia.

verses.textEn: But Simon took up a position at Addus, opposite the face of the plains.
verses.textLa: Simon autem applicuit in Addus contra faciem campi.

verses.textEn: And when Trypho realized that Simon rose up in the place of his brother, Jonathan, and that he would be joining in battle with him, he sent messengers to him,
verses.textLa: Et ut cognovit Tryphon quia surrexit Simon loco fratris sui Ionathæ: et quia commissurus esset cum eo prælium, misit ad eum legatos,

verses.textEn: saying: “We have detained your brother, Jonathan, because of the money that he owed to the king’s account, because of the matters for which he was responsible.
verses.textLa: dicens: Pro argento, quod debebat frater tuus Ionathas in ratione regis, propter negotia, quæ habuit, detinuimus eum.

verses.textEn: And now, send a hundred talents of silver, and two of his sons for hostages, so that when he is dismissed, he may not flee from us. And then we will release him.”
verses.textLa: Et nunc mitte argenti talenta centum, et duos filios eius obsides, ut non dimissus fugiat a nobis, et remittemus eum.

verses.textEn: And Simon knew that he was speaking deceitfully to him. Yet he ordered the money and the boys to be given, lest he should bring upon himself a great hostility from the people of Israel, who might have said,
verses.textLa: Et cognovit Simon quia cum dolo loqueretur secum, iussit tamen dari argentum, et pueros: ne inimicitiam magnam sumeret ad populum Israel, dicentem:

verses.textEn: “It is because he did not send the money and the boys that he perished.”
verses.textLa: Quia non misit ei argentum, et pueros, propterea periit.

verses.textEn: So he sent the boys and one hundred talents. And he was lying and did not dismiss Jonathan.
verses.textLa: Et misit pueros, et centum talenta: et mentitus est, et non dimisit Ionathan.

verses.textEn: And after this, Trypho came into the country, to crush it. And they circled around by the way that leads to Adora. And Simon and his camp marched into every place, wherever they went.
verses.textLa: Et post hæc venit Tryphon intra regionem, ut contereret eam: et gyraverunt per viam, quæ ducit Ador: et Simon, et castra eius ambulabant in omnem locum quocumque ibant.

verses.textEn: But those who were in the stronghold sent messengers to Trypho, so that he would hurry to come through the desert, and to send them provisions.
verses.textLa: Qui autem in arce erant, miserunt ad Tryphonem legatos, ut festinaret venire per desertum, et mitteret illis alimonias.

verses.textEn: And Trypho prepared all his horsemen to arrive on that night. But there was a very great snowfall, and he did not come into Gilead.
verses.textLa: Et paravit Tryphon omnem equitatum, ut veniret illa nocte: erat autem nix multa valde, et non venit in Galaaditim.

verses.textEn: And when he approached toward Baskama, he killed Jonathan and his sons there.
verses.textLa: Et cum appropinquasset Bascaman, occidit Ionathan, et filios eius illic.

verses.textEn: And Trypho turned back and went into his own land.
verses.textLa: Et convertit Tryphon, et abiit in terram suam.

verses.textEn: And Simon sent and took the bones of Jonathan, his brother, and he buried them in Modin, the city of his fathers.
verses.textLa: Et misit Simon, et accepit ossa Ionathæ fratris sui, et sepelivit ea in Modin civitate patrum eius.

verses.textEn: And all Israel bewailed him with great lamentation. And they mourned him for many days.
verses.textLa: Et planxerunt eum omnis Israel planctu magno, et luxerunt eum dies multos.

verses.textEn: And Simon built, over the sepulcher of his father and of his brothers, a building, lofty to see, of polished stone, front and back.
verses.textLa: Et ædificavit Simon super sepulchrum patris sui et fratrum suorum ædificium altum visu, lapide polito retro et ante:

verses.textEn: And he set up seven pyramids, one against another, for his father, and his mother, and his four brothers.
verses.textLa: Et statuit septem pyramidas, unam contra unam patri et matri, et quatuor fratribus:
verses.notes: The seventh pyramid was apparently for himself. For he thought that he would die as his brothers had died.

verses.textEn: And around these he placed great columns; and upon the columns, weapons, as a continual memorial; and beside the weapons, carvings of ships, which might be seen by all those who sail the sea.
verses.textLa: et his circumposuit columnas magnas: et super columnas arma, ad memoriam æternam: et iuxta arma naves sculptas, quæ viderentur ab omnibus navigantibus mare.

verses.textEn: This is the sepulcher that he made in Modin, even to this day.
verses.textLa: Hoc est sepulchrum, quod fecit in Modin, usque in hunc diem.

verses.textEn: But Trypho, when he was on a journey with the young king, Antiochus, killed him by deceit.
verses.textLa: Tryphon autem cum iter faceret cum Antiocho rege adolescente, dolo occidit eum.

verses.textEn: And he reigned in his place, and he put on the diadem of Asia, and he caused great scourges upon the land.
verses.textLa: Et regnavit loco eius, et imposuit sibi diadema Asiæ, et fecit plagam magnam in terra.

verses.textEn: And Simon built up the strongholds of Judea, fortifying them with high towers, and great walls, and gates and bars. And he placed provisions in the fortresses.
verses.textLa: Et ædificavit Simon præsidia Iudææ, muniens ea turribus excelsis, et muris magnis, et portis, et seris: et posuit alimenta in munitionibus.

verses.textEn: And Simon chose men, and he sent to king Demetrius, so that he would grant a remission to the region, for all that Trypho did was to carry out plundering.
verses.textLa: Et elegit Simon viros, et misit ad Demetrium regem ut faceret remissionem regioni: quia actus omnes Tryphonis per direptionem fuerant gesti.

verses.textEn: And king Demetrius responded to this word, and he wrote a letter in this manner:
verses.textLa: Et Demetrius rex ad verba ista respondit ei, et scripsit epistolam talem:

verses.textEn: “King Demetrius to Simon, the high priest and friend of kings, and to the elders, and to the people of the Jews: greetings.
verses.textLa: REX Demetrius Simoni summo sacerdoti, et amico regum, et senioribus, et genti Iudæorum salutem.

verses.textEn: The golden crown and the bahem that you sent, we have received. And we are prepared to make a great peace with you, and to write to the officers of the king to remit to you the things that we have released.
verses.textLa: Coronam auream, et bahem, quam misistis, suscepimus: et parati sumus facere vobiscum pacem magnam, et scribere præpositis regis remittere vobis quæ indulsimus.
verses.notes: The word ‘bahem’ is not Latin, but Hebrew. It means ‘in them,’ or ‘in which,’ or ‘through them,’ but is used in this context to refer to something that is symbolic of living by the Jewish faith. It is usually awkwardly translated as ‘palm.’ The original Douay-Rheims translation leaves the word as ‘bahem’ and notes that it refers to some type of religious chain or jewelry. The Wycliffe translation also leave the word untranslated.

verses.textEn: For whatever we have established remains in force for you. The strongholds that you have built, let them be yours.
verses.textLa: Quæcumque enim constituimus, vobis constant. Munitiones, quas ædificastis, vobis sint.

verses.textEn: Likewise, any oversight or fault, even to this day, we forgive it, along with the crown that you owed. And if anything else was taxed in Jerusalem, now let it not be taxed.
verses.textLa: Remittimus quoque ignorantias, et peccata usque in hodiernum diem, et coronam, quam debebatis: et siquid aliud erat tributarium in Ierusalem, iam non sit tributarium.

verses.textEn: And if any of you is fit to be enrolled among our own, let them be enrolled. And let there be peace between us.”
verses.textLa: Et si qui ex vobis apti sunt conscribi inter nostros, conscribantur, et sit inter nos pax.

verses.textEn: In the one hundred and seventieth year, the yoke of the Gentiles was taken away from Israel.
verses.textLa: Anno centesimo septuagesimo ablatum est iugum Gentium ab Israel.

verses.textEn: And the people of Israel began to write in the tablets and the public records, in the first year under Simon: high priest, great commander, and leader of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Et cœpit populus Israel scribere in tabulis, et gestis publicis, anno primo sub Simone summo sacerdote, magno duce, et principe Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: In those days, Simon took up a position at Gaza, and he encamped around it, and he made machines of war, and he applied them to the city, and he struck one tower and captured it.
verses.textLa: In diebus illis applicuit Simon ad Gazam, et circumdedit eam castris, et fecit machinas, et applicuit ad civitatem, et percussit turrem unam, et comprehendit eam.

verses.textEn: And those who were within the machine broke forth into the city. And a great commotion occurred in the city.
verses.textLa: Et eruperant qui erant intra machinam in civitatem: et factus est motus magnus in civitate.
